editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: THE MARROVV OF COMPLEMENTS.
OR, A most Methodicall and accurate forme of Instructions for all Variety of Love-Letters, Amorous Discourses, and Complementall Entertainements.
Fitted for the use of all sorts of persons from the Noblemans Palace to the Artizans Shop.

p.hi: With many delightfull Songs, Sonnetts, Odes, Dialogues, &c.

div.p: Never before published.
LONDON, July. 15 Printed for Humphrey Moseley, and are to be sold at his shop at the Princes Armes in St. Pauls Church-yard. 1655. 1654

div.head: To the (unbiassed) Reader.
div.p:
MY former Indeavours in matter of this nature, found such candid acceptance (for which I acknowledge my selfe obliged in all the bonds of gratefull service) at your hands, that I harbour not the least diffidence of your courteous reception of this, which includes the Summe and Marrow of all former contrivances of this nature, and yet not with the least dependencie upon any of them, with far more varietie (considering it's bulke) of fancie and sublimity of sense; I know Socrates (though perhaps in private he sport with his Cattamite) will cast a frowning countenance upon these Amorous pieces: Diogenes will be dogged, Cato censorious and Curio currish; but this is onely a varnish to their (clandestine venery, for in private the crabbedst Crittick of them all, will with more willingnesse peruse these facetious fancies, then turne o're some voluminous Rabbin: I say not that when the to takes their blood (I meane when they are disposed for mirth and galliardizing) they will not blush to make mee their Tutor, and the Simpring Citizens wife, who canonizes Lucreece for at least a Saint, and (could she attaine it would (seemingly) prize the rustie •… gger that dismissed her soule at as high a rate as
Romes Catholicks doe St. Bonaventures vestment, yet (in her closet) will peruse me with more veneration then she would Perkins or Playford; I am sensible (my honoured Readers) what harsh censures have past upon my former pieces, notwithstanding for your sakes, I have here adventured once againe to make trial of mens minds, (this being my ultimum vale) this if your noble dispositions shall like well of (or if you will but reasonably respect what your selves haue drawne me to) I shall be nothing displesed at others cavills, but resting my selfe contented with your good opinions scorne all the Rabble of uncharitable Detractors,

closer.signed: Ever acknowledging my selfe Your devoted Servant PHILOMUSUS.

div.head:
THE MARROW OF COMPLEMENT. Comprising the Sum and Substance of all Books of this nature hitherto divulged in a more methodicall, Concise and Accurate forme, then in any volume yet extant, and consisting Of
Amorous Epistles, or Love-Letters.
Complementall Entertainments.
Facetious Dialogues.
Presentations of Gifts.
Instuctions for Wooers.
Songs, and Sonnets.
With other pleasant passages never before published.
div.p: A Young Gentleman being surprized with the love of a Mayd or Widdow, (whom he accidentally cast his eyes upon) and not having opportunity to solicit in person, may thus Importune by her Letter.

div.head: TRACT. 1. Epistle 1.
div.p: LEt it not appeare Impudence, that I who am (altogether) a stranger to your person (though not to your worth) should assume such confidence, as to be solicitous (at first time) for the attaining a grant from your faire selfe, that I may bee numbred amongst the principall of those who devoutly Adore you. I confesse I have little incouragement to beg such a Boone, having yet not so much as attempted any thing that might make me capable of your smiles; yet such is the all-commanding power of Ʋenus sonne, that though but once my eyes were so happy to take a view of your Divine perfections, and though the thunder of your deniall (with sawcie Salmoneus) pash me to pieces, I must stand the shock (and though in griefe) with awfull reverence expire. But (Divine Lady) if that that tendernesse and moliitie inherent and predominant in your soft sex sway its Scepter in you, I will hope I shall not long languish, wanting the enjoyment of your Love, without the fruition whereof I am for ever lost; but which way soever the Destinies appoint your heart to dispose of me, no adverse fortune shall be of force ever to make me deny that I am,

closer.signed: Bright Lad, Wholy yours, in all the bonds of affectionate service, T. R.

div.head: A MADRIGALL.
div.l: Oh why,
Injurious Time,
Dost thou constraine that I
Should perish in my youths sweet prime!
I, but a while ago (you cruell cruell powers)
In spight of Fortune cropt contentments flowers,
And still untouch'd, as at some safer Games,
Plaid with the coales of love, & beauties flames;
But now for trying this in vaine
I'm sunk and neer shall rise again:
Thē let despair set sorrows string
To strains that dolefull be,
And I will sing
Ah me!

div.head: ANOTHER.
div.l: Thy leave
My dying Song
Yet take, ere griefe bereave
The breath which I enjoy too long;
Tell thou that fair one, this, my Soule prefers
Her Love above my life, and that I died hers:
And now farwell thou place of my curst birth,
where once I breath'd the sweetest aire on earth;
Since me my wonted Joyes forsake
And all my trust deceive,
Of all I take
My leave.

div.head: A PARADOX. Proving that Children may, without scruple, marry without their Parents consent.
div.l: IT is no marvell many matches bee
Concluded without Parents privitie;
Since Parents by base Avarice misled
Their Interest in that have forfeited.

div.head: A Pleasant Dialogue maintained between a lustfull young man, and a chast-minded Maide, in the persons of ALERANE and MODESTA.

lg.l: SWeetest Modesta (now alone we are)
I see that in Loves Hieroglyphicks you
Seem to be little studied, wherefore here
I'm come to be your Tutor, and bestow
My dearest skill, being grieved much to see
You in the best of Arts unlearned bee.
The language of that Love, and of that praise
I showred thick upon you day by day,
You understood not, though ten thousand waies
I tride to write it plaine, and what I pray
Meant all that sweet adoe, but onely this,
That we might mutually embrace and kiss?
When on your Chrystall fountaine thou dost looke,
The Nymph cannot but smile to think that shee,
Is by thy selfe each evening made the booke
Where thy sweet face is printed; woe is mee
Why was I not a fountaine too, that thou
The same reflection migh'st to me allow.
The Moon betimes repayreth to thine eye,
And ask's what weather Heaven shall have that day,
In vain the clouds combine to damp the skie,
If thou thy beames with freedome dost display;
If thou but lowr'st in vaine the foolish Ayre
Forceth her selfe to smile, and to looke faire.
As from Arabia, winds this way doe hie,
From thy faire mouth they snatch their balmy breath
Into their own, and as they forward flie
With gallant Odours they perfume their path,
The world admires, whence such rich blasts should fly,
But none the sweet originall know but I.
For strange unto thy selfe thou needst will bee,
And take no notice of all excellence
Which in thy heart doth hold it's Monarchie;
I tell thee (sweete) 'tis but a fond pretence
Which thou call'st modestie, and might undo thee,
If Providence had not sent me unto thee.
Canst thou imagine Nature ever meant
To plant the best of all her store in thee,
There to lie hid and die, and not be spent
In the free course of naturall charitie.
Let those be chast who can no love invite,
'Twere sin in thee, who art made for delight.
NO hast (good Sir) if that you love me so,
Heare me a little as I you have done;
Hast very seldome with successe doth goe,
But doth all fortune but the bad out-run.
How then can headlong lust a good end find,
When both it selfe, and its fond god are blind?
Were they not so, how could'st thou me invite
To those strange joyes, which must lie sneaking in
The guilty curtaines and avoyd the light,
As one too faire a witnesse for a sin
So foule and black; by this aforehand thou
Ashamed art of what thou faine would'st do.
The Act would make me seem so black, that thou
Who now both lov'st me, and admir'st me so,
For meere deformity would'st never know
Me more, but scorn'd and hated let me go.
So would I do my selfe and never stay,
Knew I how from my selfe to run away.

div.head: A Batchelour, or a Widdower having been long Suiter to a Maide or Widdow, and finding himselfe far distant from his hopes, thus (amorously) informes her of the danger of deniall. EPIST. 2.
div.p: I Beseech you consider that your coyness is quite contrary to natures ordination, who created you faire (like your selfe) Aenigmatically intimating, that (with her) you should take delight frankly to bestow your favours: she (generous Lady) smiles upon those who protest themselves her profest enemies, how great reason have you then to behold him with an auspicious eye, whose life and fortunes lie prostrate at your feet.

q.l: Why, my Dearest, should that face
And feature, have a Cyphers place?

div.p: Nay, more (bright beauty) you have just cause to feare that heaven will inflict severe vengeance on you for this abstemiousnesse; for we reade, that Anaxarete and others, who shewed themselves obdurate, and implacable towards their submissive Suters, and were metamorphosed into Stones, Trees, and other unrelenting substances, but Ariadne, Calisto, and others that courteously received their Lovers Devotions, retributing their respects, and returning them Love for Regard, were either made Illustrious Deities, eminent constellations, or refulgent Starres; thus not doubting but upon mature deliberation, you will disclaime the fate of the first, and desire the felicity of the latter, I humbly take my leave, kissing your faire hands, and remaining

closer.signed: Your devout Adorer E. B.

div.head: The lover having seene his Mistresse weare a bunch of Roses, may thus expresse his fancy by way of complementall asseveration.
div.l: THose Roses blusht whē neer your lips they came,
Whose purer crimson, and whose sweeter breath
They thought (& wel they might) their double shame
No Lillie ever met you in his path;
But if your hand did touch it straight in Spight,
'Twas pale to see it selfe out-vi'd in white.

div.head: A kind hearted Lasse, having surrendred all that shee could call hers to the will of her beloved, and now finding her selfe big about the belly sends this letter to hed paramour desiring the consummation of his promise. EPIST. 3.
div.p:
THe fruit of our private dalliance is now become so publick and so obvious to every eye (the reason why I am constrained to make my selfe a Recluse) that any man may run and reade it, I feele an active thing [every morning] sporting in my womb, and dauncing Levaltos with agile motion, which makes me conceipt that he will not onely (like thy selfe) prove a Master of Musick, but also an excellent caperer: you know that ere I could be won to satiate your desires, I had your firme promise to make me your wife; I dream't last night, that I saw HYMEN, and the God of Marriage involving our hands, and incorporating our hearts (deare heart) you must not be tardy in your stay, for my condition denounceth defiance to prolixity, make hast there fore, and prevent your own and my disgrace: disgrace said I — your owne and my certaine ruine. You know the late — Act of Parliament makes our late amorous compliance no lesse then death, let not you and I bee the first oblation offered up to the Justice of that stearne Edict: you will say I speake merrily, but in good earnest (deare) there is much danger in delay, make no tarrying therefore, but with volatile hast, let us set
forward to the Temple, and there receive a pattent and protection for our embraces,

closer.signed: Yours more then my own. A. K.

div.head: CUPID, A DANGEROVS INMATE.
div.l: VVHat horrors haunt a lovers mind,
Passing those bounds that are assign'd
By Nature; every thing we see
But Love can well confined bee;
Herbs yeeld a cure for every wound,
But for Loves cure, no vertue's found.
O happhy then is his Estate
That for Loves Darts, Invulnerate.

lg.l: SAd eyes what doe you ayle
To be thus ill disposed?
Why doth your sleeping faile,
Now all mens else are closed?
Wast I that never did bow
Unto any servile duty,
And will you make me now
A slave to Love and beauty?
What hope have I that she
Will hold her favour ever,
When so few women be
That constant can persever?
Doe not poore heart depend
On those vaine thoughts that fill thee,
They'l faile thee in the end;
So must thy passions kill thee.
Shall then in earnest truth
My carefull eyes observe her?
Shall I consume my youth
And spend my strength to serve her?
Shall I beyond my strength
Let passions torments prove mee,
To heare her say at length,
Away, I cannot love thee?

div.head: The Passions of Love, or a Description of of the severall waies of wooing, according to the various humors and inclinations of Men.
div.p: THere is one sort of Lovers, whose qualities (I think) is known to few, whose humours wee will communicate.

div.head: The first Passion.
div.p: Those seek by all meanes possible to accrew each Virgins liking, sometimes attaining the thing they desire they become extreme sorry, and wish they were without it [perchance having before placed their affection where it cannot or must not totally remove] and yet if they faile to procure their desires, no men more dejected then they.

div.head: The Second Passion.
div.p:
Some are infected with such humours (and this was Nasos Disease) that sometimes non are lovely in their
eyes, but faire women, anon they will sweare to you there is no heed to be taken to the colour of the face; afterwards the brown is the only laudable complexion, sometimes the wanton, sometimes the modest eye, sometimes the simple, soone after the subtile Girle are only in fashion.

div.head: The third Passion.
div.p: The man (and he perhaps no small foole both for wealth and repute) straines his wit to Poetize, painting his passion forth in verse, but in this blockish age that practise little prevailes, nor doe I wonder wit is of so little force in such cases, since I see daily Dunces can have sometimes at a cheap rate, and s • nd them as their own, when some other was the Authour.

div.head: The Fourth Passion.
div.p: Another he brings with him many silent Oratours, viz. Baggs of mony, and verily he takes the surest course, and that woman that non-suits him in such a case, were worth the favour of a Prince.

div.head: The fift Passion.
div.p: This fellow that hath neither Valour nor wit will come ruffling into his Mistrisses presence, and with shamelesse braggs and lyes (making a stately, proud, vaineglorious shew of many greater matters) and though he be not heire to one foot of land, yet he will tell her many fine tales of castles in the Ayre, and for martiall matters, he will relate of fraies, of passadoes, and Stockadoes, and that nothing may be wanting to approve him truly accomplish'd, he can poetize too for a need, culling many curious conceits out of Shakespire or Fletcher.

div.head: The sixt Passion.
div.p: Another shallow braine hath no device, but prates of some strange luck he had at the Cards, or at the Tables, bragging of his play so long, till in short time he put his Mistresse Love (more then) to the hazzard.

div.head: The seventh Passion.
div.p: But some there are (marry fie upon 'em) that make themselves as like their Mistresses, as they can (fine In'amoratos) hoping thereby to win their loves, they order their lookes, faine their pace, &c. monstrum horendum &c.

div.head: The eight Passion.
div.p: There are those that woe by nodds and lookes, and sure their progenitors were Apes.

div.head: The ninth Passion.
div.p: One for some certaine dayes or weekes, or (perhaps) moneths, weares a branch of withered Bayes in his hat, or sweares with his utmost indeavours to preserve some flowers, he drinkes healths upon his bare knees, sues mainely for a shoe-string, or buskepoint.

div.head: The tenth Passion.
div.p: Another I have noted (like an Asse) to walke by his Mistresse window, with what a fained pace the woodcock will stalke, as if he numbred all the starres in the firmament, t'would make one swel with laughter, to see how many errands from sun to sun he will make that way, carrying himselfe as if his Mistresse eye were alwaies upon him, when she perhaps laughs at his folly, flouts, ok lookes quite from him.

div.head: A Maide or Widdow having long beene in league with one that (seemingly) was her faithfull friend, and now finding him inconstant, and affianced to another, may thus take notice of his perfidiousnesse. EPIST. 4.
div.l: I Have heard tell, and now I find,
Out of sight, and out of mind.
And that 'twas truly said of old,
Love that's soonest hot, is soonest cold.
Else my teares had now not staind
The paper, nor my lines complaind.
Nor I been forced to have sent
These Nuncios of my discontent.
Not exchan'gd so unhappily
My mirth, to write an Elegy.
But since fate wills I must doe so,
Doe not dare to flout my wo,
Or reade my sorrowes with a scoff,
Yet reade them ere thou cast them off:
And though thou canst not feele compassion,
Not pittying doe not blame my passion:
Thou knowst (alasse that er'e 'twas known,
A time there was (though that times gone)
I that scarce dare a Begger bee,
That time might have commanded thee.
But see how things may hap to change,
(Time was we were not halfe so strange:)
But oft embrac'd with gentle greeting,
Thou callst me Dove, I thee my Sweeting.
Yea, and had but those vowes of thine
Prov'd but as faithfull as were mine;
Stil't had been so (I do not fain)
And would it might be so again:
Sith thy Love cooles, and thou unkind,
Be not displeas'd I breath my mind,
Hoping my words may prove a Mirrour
Wherein thou maist behold thy Error.
Dear, I hope I may call thee so,
(Th'art dear to me, although a foe)
Is't true that I do hear of thee
(Oh how true it appears to be!)
Can such things be i'th Court of Love,
False man, that thou so vain shouldst prove?
Thou that erewhile so pensive sate,
Thou that didst service vow of late:
Art thou that Lover whose sad eye
Seldome was in my presence drie,
And from whose fluent tongue I know
So many moving words could flow?
Which made me think thee without stain
And yeeld thee Love for Love again.
Wearied with Love art thou estranged?
Is thy affection so much changed?
Then true I finde, what ere this day
I feard, and heard some wiser say,

l.hi: There's nought on earth so sweet that can
Long please a curious tasted man.

div.l: Well, take thy course, Traytor, farewell,
Ere long thou'lt hear my passing Bell.

closer.signed: The hater of thy perfidiousnesse as much as can possibly be imagined M. R.

div.head: CASVALL COMPLEMENTS. A Gentleman meeting (in a company) at Tavern, or elsewhere, with three Gentlewomen, whom he is disposed to court, may thus complement with them one after another, in a different Dialect.
With the first thus.
div.p: MAdam, your beautie is so bright, that I must ingenuously acknowledg it surpasseth all that ever I saw, and there is no Lady under the cope to whom I durst safely protest so much affection, as to your excellent selfe; were your thoughts but correspondent to my Love, I might truly record my self the happiest man in the world; otherwise, I am sensible I cannot long survive, which will consequently confirm that you are the efficient cause of my death. Madam, I beseech you adopt me your servant (using me and all I call mine as your owne) for I esteem it impossible to receive a more transcendent favour from Heaven, then to record my selfe your vassall.

div.head: To the second thus.
div.p: Lady, I cannot but yeeld you a narration of the fervent Love I bear you, and must while I bear my selfe about me; could I obtain the reflection of your favour, I should esteem my selfe the happiest man upon earth; therefore (bright Beauty) affecting you as I doe, disdain not I beseech you the sacrifice of an humble heart, since my utmost blisse, or assured ruine, is folely at your appointment.

div.head: To the third thus.
div.p:
Madam, perhaps I may seem unto you to be too rash and heady, having no more but seen you, and
yet at the first sight to manifest the entire love and ardent affection that I bear unto you, for which you ought not to blame me, but your beautie, which rendreth you an earthly Dietie, and commandeth me to become your Prisoner; if then your admirable beauty and shape be inriched (as questionlesse it is) with as fair and amiable a Soule, I dare not doubt but you will chuse rather to retribute my affection, then permit your deniall to precipitate me into the gulph of despair.

div.head: AN ODE.
div.l: I Dy
For oh I feele,
Deaths horrors drawing nie
And all this frame of Nature reele
My hopelesse heart despayring of reliefe
Sinks underneath the weight of saddest griefe,
Which hath so ruthless torne, so tortur'd every veine,
All comfort comes too late to cure't againe.
My head begins to dance Deaths giddy round,
A shivering chilness doth each sense cōfound;
Benum'd is my cold brow,
A dimness shuts my eye,
Oh now, ô now
I Die.

lg.l: VVHen she sits, me thinks I see
How all vertues fixed be
In a frame, whose constant mould
Will the same unchanged hold.
If you note her when she moves,
Cytherea drawne with Doves
May come learn with winning motions
Which way to attract Devotions.
Lift your wondring eyes and see,
Whether ought can better'd be.

div.head: A complementall Letter to some brave and noble Lady, a Gentleman being desirous to expresse the height of Fancy. EPIST. 5.
div.p:
SInce the Paphian Deitie hath been pleased to permit me to have a sight of your excellent self, (indeed the true Ʋenus and the Goddesse of all perfection) she must be contented, if I (for the future) offer up my Orisons only on the Altar of your beauty, neglecting her counterfeit supremacy. I was never till now a diligent Devoto, but have done homage to Cupid onely at odde howers, oft-times with reluctancy, ever with lubricitie; but having made an infallible survey of your heavenly worth and celestiall claritie,
He must be wilder then woods whom you
Cannot melt down with your admired hew,
Which tames Birds, Plants, & Beasts, which grase & feed
More then ere Orpheus with his Musick did.
Your Golden tresses pure Ambrosian
Fairer then all the twists Arachne span,
Shine far more bright then Phoebus glistering raies
By all mens judgments meriting more praise.
Your corrall lips (those ruddy potts of pleasure)
Do seem to open to whole mines of treasure.
Your Breasts two Ivory Mounts (mounts may I call them
For many veiles of pleasant veines empall them:
These like two borders doe such sweets display,
Who lodges there attaines the Milkie way,
Whtn Titan peeps into your presence chamber,
You doe reflect him with your locks of Amber,
Each other greeting, as that then were there
Two Suns at once both in one Hemisphere:
If Zeuxes pictured grapes so lively were,
That many birds in flocks repaired there,
Pecking upon his statues, and did browse
Upon his lively grapes [meer lively showes]
Well may we think that Natures selfe can make
A farre more lively and proportion'd shape
Then a poor painter, though his grapes seem ripe,
Yet they were drawn from her first Archetype.
Then Joves best picture, Natures admiration,
Let me teach you the use of your creation,

I say, since I know how fit you are to be ador'd, and in what an obligation all mortalls are bound to your supream selfe, I beg that you will please to list me in the number of your admirers; for be pleased (bright Goddesse) to know, that no mortall breathing shall manifest more ardency of affection, and affectionate ardency, then

closer.signed: Your admirer and sworn servant E. D.

div.head: A Country Courtship.
div.l: SIt thee down in this Arbour (sweet)
Where all the Wood-Nymphs use to meet,
Making such mellifluous sound,
As glads the Birds and deserts round.
The Nymphs their prayers shall renew,
And chaunt their Hymns to pleasure you.
The Nine shall from their hill descend,
(To us attendance they shall Lend)
And if any discord be,
They shall yeeld a remedy.
Euterpe, Thalia, and Caliope,
Terpsy chore, Ʋrania the sweet,
Poly-hymnia singing at thy feet;
These shall grace thee on this plain
If thou canst love a country Swain.
The sweetest spices of Arabia,
And the best perfumes of Lydia
Shall breath upon thee, till thou lie
Buried in beds of Spicery.
See on yonder verdant hill
How two honest Turtles Bill,
And in Loving tones comply,
Beckning unto thee and I,
To imitate their amorous mirth
(Love is the life of all on earth)
See how Titan huggs his hap,
VVhile he sports in Tellus lap,
She smiling, with her fingers faire
Wreaths, Golden Garlands of his hair.
All things courteously combine,
And shall we hate the divine
Dictates of Love? come let us clip,
Let me suck Nectar from thy lip.
Here's no jealous lowring eye
To fascinate our felicitie.
This is no Dodonean Grove,
No Tree here will divulge our Love;
Nor need we fear a foul surprise
By the rustick Deities.
Pan, Silvanus, Faunus, or
Pallas they all sporting are
With the Hamadriades,
And the wing'd Oreades.
Come (my dearest) let us try,
—Out on this fond nicetie
So; this yeelding doth proclaim
I have not mistooke my Ayme.

div.head: EPIST. 6. The lover having received a full and finall deniall from his Mistresse, and yet she afterwards altering her mind, and proffering him what before he could not attain, and he resolving to loath what he before lov'd, may return her this answer.
div.p: YOu may aswell forbear either your sighs or flatteries, since I now am resolved neither the dolour of the one, nor the allurements of the other shall be of force to alter my firm fixed resolution; never more to solicite her who hath so much slighted me: you may as easily out-noise the wind, and restore Cupid to his eyes, as change the tenor of my mind: I have lov'd you too long, and it is time now that I become sensible of mine owne worth and your levitie: can you hope to kindle a new flame, where there are lest no sparks of old desire? you are pleased prodigally to protest that you now love me infinitely, I will believe you, and desire no better confirmation thereof then that you trouble me no more, &c.

closer.signed: Not yours, but his owne, G. D.

div.head: The way to chuse a Mistresse

lg.l: A Face that is exactly fair,
Neither long nor circular:
A Brow, where neither age nor yet
Peevishnesse hath wrinkles set;
Black eyes,
The windowes of the Edifice
Not staring out:
Nor rowling wantonly about
Their Orbs equall, parted by
A Nose of purest Ivory:
Her colour mixt, so that the eye
Can't say that here the red doth lye,
Or here the white, each part as loth
To yeeld, yet equally hath both
A Breath
Might revive one at point of death:
Vying with the Panchayan Groves
When their tops an East wind moves;
Lips blushing to be known,
Kissing by the lookers on.
Not still dispos'd
To talk, nor yet in silence clos'd,
Her Teeth white, a dimpled Chin,
And clothed with the purest skin.
Then as good painters use to place
Dark shadowes to the fairest face.
Sad brown hair, whose curles may tie
Those Pris'ners taken by her eye.
Her Minde
Cloth'd in vertue, not behind
The others beautie, he that can
Attain this Nymph's a happy man.

div.head: A Woman refusing to shew her Face.
div.l: CLouded thus,
Most men wil think you leporous
Woman would never court her glasse
If man did never court her face.
We men make you what you are
Whether you are wise or faire.
Our praises
Your glory raises,
And are the Gailes
That so proudly swell vour sayles:
Then withdraw this cloud that doth
Wrong your beautie and your youth.

div.head: TRACT 2. EPIST 7. The Lover having adopted himselfe Servant to a beautie that would make him believe she bath vowed Chastitie, may thus informe her by Letter.
div.l: YOu tell me you could love me above many,
But are resolv'd never to marry any.
One is no number, Mayds are then
Nothing without the aid of men;
You would live single, thou shalt be
Single, though Hymen couple thee.
Wild Savages that drink of springs
Think water best of earthly things;
But they that tast sweet wine despise it,
Virginitie, though some do prize it
Compar'd with Marriage (trie them both)
Differ as wine from water doth.
This Idoll call'd Virginitie
Is neither essence to the eye,
Nor any one exterior sense,
Nor hath it place of residence:
Nor earth, nor mould Celestiall,
Nor hath it any form at all:
Of that which is not, do not boast
Things that are not, can't be lost.
Foolish men call it vertuous;
What vertue is't, thats born with us?
Can honour be ascribd thereto?
Honour is gaind by things we doe.
Seek you for immortall fame,
Some have wrongd Dianaes name:
Be she false, or be she not,
Be she fair, vile tongues will blot;
But you are fair, most wondrous fair,
Gentle, young, and debonair;
They'l think if thus you live alone,
That some man keeps you as his owne.
Then (dearest) doe not from me flie
Following banefull infamy:
For be assur'd 'mongst all the race of men
None can yeeld Jupiter more honour then.

closer.signed: I dare prostrate at your feet G. K.

div.head: The Lover being absent from his Mtstresse, in a farre distant Country (having already made himselfe sure by contract) and hearing from his affected one (by Letter) that in his absence, her Parents and friends indeavoured to frustrate his desires (she notwithstanding assuring him of her owne firm fixed constancy) may return her this answer.
div.p: I Esteem it a superlative happinesse to hear that your Love to me is Armour of proofe against your Parents perswasions and threats, so that you cannot be betrayed by the one, nor destroyed by the other: be confident (my dear) that all the force of the world, though contracted in one, shall not be sufficient to cause in me the least relaxation of that Love I have sworn to practise, and which I am now doubly obliged to make manifest. Oh the ineffable felicitie that they enjoy who have a harmony of hearts, and whose wishes meet in one center: I will once again attempt both in person and by proxy, to winne the assent of your Parents in reference to their countenancing of our intended Nuptialls; but if again my endeavours prove ineffectuall, I shall think the crime at least but veniall, if contrary to their consents, we consummate Hymens rites, till the happy perpetration whereof, there cannot be the least reall comfort expected by

closer.signed: Your affectionate Lover and Servant E. K.

div.head: A Song in Dialogue between a Lover and his Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Lover.
sp.l: SVVeet let us here enjoy the shade
(Though envy of this shadow be)
Yet Love in shadow best is made,
Non brooks Sols lustre worse then he.

sp.speaker: Mistresse.
sp.l: Where Love doth shine, there needs no Sunne
(Without Love, all the World were dark)
All lights into his one doth run,
Yet he himselfe is but a spark.

div.head: A Complemental onset, this being the first time the woer solicits his Mistresse.
div.p: I Neede not here tell you, you are faire or lovely, or how well you dresse you (Lady) Ile save my selfe that Eloquence of your glasse, which can speake such things better farre then I, and tis a knowledge wherein fooles may be as wise as a court — &c.
Or thus.

I Have no ends upon you (Lady) more then this, to tell you how Love beauties good Angell hee that waits upon her, at all occasions (and no lesse then Fortune helps the adventurers) in me makes that proffer, which never faire one was so fond to lose, who could but reach a hand out to her freedome (Lady I speake in reference to your Guardian, whose strictnesse will not let you be your selfe) on the first sight I lov'd you, think on it Lady) be your mind as active as is your beauty; view your object well, examine both my fashion and my yeares, things that are like are soone familiar, things that are soone familiar, and nature joyes still in equality, &c.

div.head: The Coy Ladies choyce, or how to chuse a Husband.

lg.l: YOung and faire
Crisped haire
black
Chesnut colour or more slack.
A soft hand,
A brow that may command,
Valiant.
His foes to daunt.
Yet no Taylor help to make him,
Being no man when's cloaths forsake him.
Bountifull
(But not to every Gull
Or every suburb Trull)
Ever honest, as his birth,
Nothing in him that is earth.
His actions such,
As to doe nothing too too much,
Not condemne,
Nor yet contemne,
From all basedesse being free
This man, or none, must marry mee.

div.head: A Song in parts, by Endimion and Julietta.

sp.speaker: Endimion.
sp.l: COme with our voyces let us warre,
Till each of us be made a starre,
And challenge all the Spheares,
Till Tygres shed salt teares.

sp.speaker: Julietta.
sp.l: At such a call, what beast or fowle,
What tree, or stone doth want a soule?
What man but must lose his
'l esse he of reason emptie is.

sp.speaker: Endimion.
sp.l: Lets mix our notes that we may prove,
To make the mountaine Quarries move;
To stay the running floods,
And call the walking woods.

sp.speaker: Iulietta.
sp.l: What need of me, doe you but sing
And touch with art the quavering string,
Sleepe, and the Grave will wake,
And stones will sence partake.

sp.speaker: Endimion.
sp.l: They say the Angels marke each deede,
And doe on inward pleasure feede,
Till ravisht they doe grow
With what they view below.

sp.speaker: Julietta.
sp.l: Oh sing not you then, lest the best
Of Angells, wishing such a feast;
Should once againe be driven
To fall from earth to heaven.

div.head: The Author inserts not this example as an encouragement to any man to solicit anothers wife, but for varietie, and to delight the Reader, gives this sportive (supposed) Inter-locution in a Dialogue between CLODIVS and MESSALINA.

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.p: I Cannot (Lady) but extreamely grieve, when I consider what a daughter of darknesse your husband makes you, lockt up from all society or object, your eye not let to looke upon a face under a conjurers (or some mould for one hollow and leane like his) but by great meanes as I now make—

sp.speaker: Massalina.
sp.p: Troth sir, what you have uttered is more then true, of my unequall and most sordid match here, with all the circumstances of my bondage; I have a husband, and a two-legg'd one, but such a moon-ling as no wit of man, or Roses can redeem from being an Asse, he is is grown too much the story of mens mouthes to scape his lading, should I make it my study, and cast all waies, yea call mankind to helpe to take his burthen off: but sir, you seem a Gentleman of vertue no lesse then blood, and one that every way lookes as he were of too good quality to entrap a credulous woman, or betray her —

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.p:
Let not the signe of the husband fright you (Lady) but ere your spring be gone, strive to enjoy it, you know flowers though faire, are oft but of one morning, all beauty doth not last untill the Autumne, you grow old even while I tell you this, those that cannot use the present, never were, nor ever shall bee accounted wise; if Love and fortune will please to
take care of us, why should wee bee wanting to our selves, this is all—what doe you answer Lady?

sp.speaker: Messalina.
sp.p: Think but how I may with safety do it, I shal trust my love and honour to you, ever presuming that you will ever thriftily husband both against this husband of mine, who, if we can change his liberall eares to other ensignes, and with some labour make a new beast of him (as he doth deserve) cannot complaine he is unkindly dealt with.

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.p: For this time then (deare Lady) ile take my leave, I know your husbands jealous eye is over us, but wee will finde a time (fairest of women) to kisse & touch, and laugh, and whisper too, and exercise those crowning courtships, for which day and the publick are not pleased to allow a man; farewell dearest Mistresse, my man shall waite you ere to morrow this time with an Epistle from me.

sp.speaker: Messalina.
sp.p: I shall expect him, and returne an answer.
— adiew deare Sir.

div.head: DIALOGVE. 2. A Conceited Complementall Inter-locution, supposed between FLORIO and FLORINDA. The Mayd or Widdow being desirous to flout and render her Inamorato ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: FAith (Mistresse) I must needs create my selfe a creature of yours.

sp.speaker: Florinda.
sp.p:
I hope (Sir) Nature hath not moulded you so Imperfectly,
that there must be a second care taken how to contrive you.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: I meane (Lady) I have a strong Ambition to serve you.

sp.speaker: Florinda.
sp.p: Ambition (Sir) seemes all things and yet is nothing, it fooles opinion into faith, nor would I have you thinke me so Superbious (or rather sottish) that I desire such haughty servitors.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: You are criticall (Lady) and desire rather to discover the sharpnesse of your wit, then the softness of your temper; I say, I desire to be link't with your sweet selfe in the bands of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Florinda.
sp.p: Hymen forbid it (Sir) I shall never endure links or chaines, you little thinke what a libertine I am, though I am no RANTER, I cannot brooke the least limitation (bands say you) what have I done worthy the forfeiture of my freedome? if this be the abstract of your Affection, good sir, attempt to oblige others, I shall but hate you for't.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: I perceive the Moone is now in Eclipse, I shall attend (Lady) till these clouds are dissipated, you women may be justly termed natures miracles, for you are very strange creatures, another time —

sp.speaker: Florinda.
sp.p: I (Sir,) I, a yeare or two; Seven hence will be a very opportune time, tis my Clymactericall yeare, —

div.head: EPIST. 8. The Lover pithily perswading his Mistresse to relinquish her virgin resolves.
div.l: THough that no God may thee deserve,
Yet for thy own sake (whom I serve)
Abandon cold Virginitie,
The Queene of Loves sole enemie,
Practise the gesture of a Nun,
When your flowry youth is don.
Pallas joyes in single life,
'Cause she cannot be a wife.
Love then, and be not tyrannous,
Heale the heart thou hast wounded thus.
Staine not thy youth with avarice,
Faire fooles love to be counted nice.
The corne dies if it be not reapt,
Beauty is lost too strictly kept.
Come then (dearest) let's not tarry,
One day more, and we will marry.

closer.signed: Which he humbly beggs, who is wholly yours not to be disobliged, T. W.

div.head: AN INVOCATION OF CVPID. The Lover desiring the assistance of his Deity for the attaining his Mistresse favour.

lg.l: Prosper mee
Loves Deitie,
Then will I thy praise rehearse
Quite throughout the Vniverse.
I will bring
An offering,
'Ile hire some Poet for thy PRIEST,
Cloth'd in Raptures richly drest.
My eyes
Shall enflame th'sacrifice,
In thy name I will all jar's
Compose and free the earth from war's.
Ile tame
Beasts by thy name,
The Phoenix shall beleeve a Mate;
The sittest meanes to propagate
The Nightingale
Sings songs of bale,
She shall change her note and mourne,
Not for her Rape, but for her scorne.
Trees grow by two and two
As they together grew.
None shall be barren, they shall beare
Gratefull issue to the yeare.
Rivers shall stay
Kisse and play
With their banks, then slowly creep
To entermingle with the Deep,
The earth shall beare
Grasse all the yeare,
And bewith lasting verdure clad,
And what (till then) she never had.

l.hi: If thou wilt ayd me whilst I wooe.

div.head: DIALOGVE. 3. (The Lover being not more taken with his Mistresse parts, then she with his perfections.) A Dialogue (Supposed) betwen Ferdinando and Euphemia.

sp.speaker: Ferdinando.
sp.p: LAdy, I esteem it a transcendent happinesse, that destinie drove me this day into this place, where I behold all excellence in Epitome, and the most excellent beauty of the World: Ile assure you (Lady) [and were it known unto you, my temper will not permit me to adulate] that I should esteem my selfe more then a Monarch, might I have the societie of your rare selfe.

sp.speaker: Euphemia.
sp.p: Sir, You are pleased to think me worthy of such Epithites as I dare not owne, and know my selfe not to merit; you are (Sir) utterly a stranger to me, and therefore must give me leave to be diffident, it were as much immodesty in me, as imbecillity in you, at first sight to settle mine affection: yet I must tell you, that never stranger found more welcome in my heart then your selfe.

sp.speaker: Ferdinando.
sp.p: Dear Lady, blesse mine ears once more with those ravishing accents; be confident my Love shall be as permanent as my service, and my service as durable as my love, both of them equivalent, and wholly devoted to you, while I am numbered amongst the living.

sp.speaker: Euphemia.
sp.p: Sir, I dare credit yout assertions, as reall expressions, and (perhaps) durst eccho them with equall ardency; but (at least for formes sake) let our motions be methodicall.

sp.speaker: Ferdinando.
sp.p: You are my better Genius, I shall devoutly doe, as you divinely dictate; may I have the happinesse to waite on you to your Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Euphemia.
sp.p: Sir, Though I have not hitherto afforded those favours, yet (that you may know I prize your person, and esteem your friendship pretious) I shall permit your proffer.

sp.speaker: Ferdinando.
sp.p: You honour me above thought.

div.head: LOVES DOCTOR, Prescribing infallible remedies for those that are Love-sick.
If taken with her Hair.
div.p: Imagine those Tresses (which vie with unshorn Apollo's curles) to be chaines and fetters, only ordained to secure thee, till the angry sentence be past.

div.head: If wounded by her eyes.
div.p: Imagine thou thy self wert the oblation, that must be offered up by those two cruel Priests.

div.head: If enamored on the Roses in her Cheeks.
div.p: Thinke that her beautie is adulterate, that she useth an oylie Fucus, which wip'd off her countenance, were the perfect picture of a parched dunghill; and though she never practis'd the art of delusion, yet believe all is counterfeit.

div.head: If taken with her voice.
div.p: Call to minde that Syrens sung farre more melodiously then she, only with an intent to devour.

div.head: If her breath seem Aromatick.
div.p: Remember that she subsists, by that which (if sucked in) would prove thy poyson.

div.head: If her body seem excellently compss'd.
div.p: Believe that it is only a Trophey raised on purpose to ruine thee, and that the monument of her beauties praise, must be built on thy breathlesse body.

q.l: But if vertue most do please thee
Then I know not how to ease thee:
Yet if she be vertuous, then
Sure she will not murther men.

div.head: The praise of the Country life. An ODE.

lg.l: GEntle Swain, good speed befall thee,
Future times shall happy call thee:
Honest Lovers shall commend thee,
And perpetuall Fame attend thee.
Happy are those Woods and Mountains,
And as happy are those Fountains,
Where contents are still excelling,
More then in a Princes dwelling.
These thy Flocks, thy clothing bring thee,
Pretty Songs the Birds do sing thee,
And what more the worth is seeing,
Heaven and Earth thy prospect being:
Thy affection reason measures,
Still most harmlesse are thy pleasures:
And if night beget thee sorrow,
Seldome staies it till the morrow.
If all men could tast that sweetness,
Kings themselves would loath their greatness:
For it such content would breed them,
As they would not think they need them.
Whether thralled or exiled,
Whether praised or reviled,
This nor that thy rest doth winne thee,
But the mind which is within thee.
Much good doo't them with their glories,
We have read in Antique stories,
And 'tis worthy well the heeding

l.hi: There's like end, where's like proceeding.

lg.l: Be thou still in thy desires
Fanning thy fair Mistresse fires:
And let never other beautie
Make thee faile in Love or dutie.

div.head: EPIST. 9. A Gentlewoman being (justly) enraged that a (quondam) Favorite of hers [whom she once admitted to rifle every treasure she was Mistresse of] should prove such a Seive, as to boast how often he hath billeted in her quarters, may thus by (Letter) make him know that she is sensible how basely he betraies himselfe and her.
div.p:
YOu confirm that which I have often heard (yet had not the grace to believe) viz. That dunghill-Spirited men, the more favours they receive, are the more animated to prejudice their Benefactors. Did I admit thee to my embraces (overcome by thy instant
Solicitations, numerous vows, and pathetick protestations) and dost thou retribute my clemency with the loss of my fame and reputation? Degenerate Monster, canst thou possibly be so sottish, as to imagine the trumpeting of my shame (in reference to &c.) can advance thy credit, or the least support thy repute amongst magnanimous and noble spirited Gentlemen; be assured, though they willingly hear thee, they inwardly abhominate thee as a degenerate villain, and a prodigie in nature; but though thine owne wickednesse be a sufficient castigation, yet I here adjure thee to surcease thy calumnious clack, or assure thy selfe thou hast not long to live, (if there be Pistols or Ponniards) which is the infallible prediction of her,

closer.signed: Who hates thee more then Hell. M. L.

div.head:
VENVS NAKED. Instructions for an Amourist, who desires to praise his Mistresse perfections from head to foot, or to particularize
With Her haire
With Her brow
With Her visage
With Her chin
With Her lips
With Her eyes
With Her Eye-browes
With Her mouth
With Her teeth
With Her cheekes
With Her eares
With Her neck
With Her brests
With Her shoulders
With Her armes
With Her bellie, &c.

lg.head: 1. Her haire.
lg.l: THere's her haire with which Love angles,
And beholders eyes intangles.
Somwhat brighter then a browne,
And her tresses waving downe
At full length, are so dispread,
They mantle her from foot to head.

lg.head: 2. Her Brow.
lg.l: Beauty there may be descride,
In the height of all her pride.

lg.head: 3. Her Visage.
lg.l: Round's her Visage, or so neare
To a roundnesse doth appeare,
That no more of length it takes
Then what best proportion makes.

lg.head: 4. Her Chin.
lg.l: Short her chin is, and yet so,
As it is just long enow.
Lovelinesse doth seeme to glory,
In that circling promontory.

lg.head: 5. Her Eyes.
lg.l: These such gentle lookes doe lend,
As might make her foe her friend.
And by their allurings move
All beholders unto Love.

lg.head: 6. Her Eye-browes.
lg.l: On those Eye-browes never yet
Did disdainfull scowling sit:
Love and goodnesse gotten thither,
Sit on equall thrones together.

lg.head: 7. Her Lips.
lg.l: Her soft Lips doe shew no dulnesse,
Full they are, in meanest fulnesse.

lg.head: 8. Her Teeth.
lg.l: These are in such order placed,
As their whitenesse is more graced.
When her Ivory teeth she buries
'Twixt her two enticing cherries,
There appeares such pleasures hidden,
As might tempt what were forbidden.

lg.head: 9. Her Mouth.
lg.l: No part is more well disposed,
Then her dainty Mouth composed;
So as there is no distortion
Thwarting that same sweet proportion.

lg.head: 10. Her Cheekes.
lg.l: This is Beauties garden plot,
Where, as in a True-loves knot;
So the Snowy Lillie growes,
Mixed with the crimson Rose.

lg.head: 11. Her Eares.
lg.l: Then (almost obscure) appeares
Those her Jewell-gracing eares;
Whose owne beauties more adorne
Then the richest pearle that's worne
By the proudest Persian Dames,
Or the best that nature frames.

lg.head: 12. Her Neck.
lg.l: 'Twixt her shoulders (meanely spread)
To support that Globe-like head
Riseth up her neck, wherein
Beauty seemeth to begin
To disclose it selfe in more
Tempting manner than before.

lg.head: 13. Her Brests.
lg.l: He that there may rest (to prove)
Softer finds those beds of Love,
Then the Cotton ripest growne,
Or fine pillars of such downe
As in time of moulting, fanns
From the breasts of silver Swanns.

lg.head: 14. Her Shoulders.
lg.l: Neither Alabaster Rocks,
Pearle-strowed-shores, nor cotswoold flocks,
Nor the mountaines tipt with snow,
Nor the milk-white Swanns of Po,
Can appeare so faire to view,
As her spotlesse Shoulders shew.

lg.head: 15. Her Armes.
lg.l: These posesse the sweetest graces,
That may apt them for embraces:
Like the silver streames they bee,
Which from some high hill we see,
Clipping in a goodly vale
That growes proud of such a thrall.

lg.head: 16. Her Hand.
lg.l: When she drawes it from her glove,
It hath vertue to remove,
Or disperst, if there be ought
Cloudeth the beholders thought.

lg.head: 17. Her Belly.
lg.l: Is a faire and matchlesse plaine,
Where unknown delights remaine:
'Tis the store-house wherein pleasure
Hides the richest of her treasure.

lg.head: 18. Her Navell.
lg.l: There they say (for mind it well)
I doe this by hearesay tell:
Growes her Navell, which doth seeme
Like some jewell of esteeme.

lg.head: A Secret.
lg.l: Somewhat else there is that's hidden,
Which to name I am forbidden:
Though I know, if none were by,
But true friends to modesty,
I might name each part at will,
And yet no mans thoughts be ill.
IN Song Apollo gives me skill,
There Love his Sisters dain,
With those that haunt Parnassus hill
I friendship entertain.
Yet this is all in vain to mee,
So haplesly I fare,
As those things which my glory be
My cause of ruine are.
For Love hath kindled in my breast
His never quenched fire:
And I who often have exprest
What other men desire,
(Because I could so dive into
The depth of others mone:)
Now I my owne affliction show,
I heeded am of none.

div.head: The Lover finding himself abus'd by her who promis'd him Marriage (she deserting him and electing another) may thus vent himselfe.
div.p:
TO make the doubt clear that no Woman can be constant, was it my fate to prove it fully in you? did I think there was but one woman that breathed pure ayre, and must she needs be as perfidious, as she is beautious? is it the mark of your youth, or splendor, or your perfection, to bid defiance to realitie? or think you Heaven is deaf, or
cannot see, or having eyes winks at your perjur'd instabilitie? are vows so cheap with women? or is the matter so liquid whereof they are made, being written in water, and blown away with every wind? who would have thought so many sweer accents, tun'd to our so many sighes, should meet blown from our hearts, sprinkled with so many oaths and tears with the divine impression of stoll'n kisses, that sealed all, should now prove but emptie nothings? did you draw bonds (Mistresse) with a mental reservation, having a full intent to forfeit? did you sign to breake, or must we take all truths that we receive from you, by the contrarie to that you speak, and find the truth out the wrong way? I sooner should have thought the Sun would have ceased to chear the earth with his beams, that Rivers would runne backward, or the Thames frozen all o're in June. May he be curst that thus hath murthered our Love, let misery in plaguing him use her utmost Art, let all eyes shunne him, and he shunne all Society, till his body become as noysome as his infamy. But my passion too much transports me, it is you (Mistresse) whom I rather ought to rail on, which (though you deserve it) because I will not do, I here conclude, committing you as a convict to the horrour of your owne conscience.

closer.signed: R. L.

div.head: The praise of an exact Beautie.
div.l: HAve you seen a Lillie grow
Before rude hands have toucht it?
Have you mark'd but the fallo'th Snow
Before the soyle hath smutcht it?
Have you felt the wool of Beaver?
Or have you felt the Swans down ever?
Or have you smelt o'th bud o'th Bryer?
Or sented Nard, thrown in the fire?
Or have you tasted the bag o'th Bee?
Oh so white, Oh so soft, Oh so sweet is shee.

div.head: The OBLIGATION. A Lover binding himselfe to performe an — imposed by his Mistresse.
div.l: BY those eyes, whose immortall fires
Serves Cupid to enflame desires;
By that forehead whence he bends
His double Bow, and's Arrows sends:
By that hayre whose globy rings
He (flying) crispeth with his wings:
By those bathes, your cheeks discloses,
Where he doth wash in Milk and Roses:
By your lip, the bank of kisses,
Where we may plant and gather blisses,
I'le fulfill your just desire,
Else let me like some dog expire.

lg.l: THough my Mistresse seem in show
Whiter then the Pyrene Snow:
Though I fitly might compare her
To the Lillies or things rarer,
Chrystall, or to ice congeal'd:
If those parts that lie conceal'd
Be others given and kept from me,
What care I how faire she be.
Though her visage did comprise
The glorious wonder of all eyes,
Captive led, she hearts in chains
Kil'd or cur'd with her disdains.
Chus'd beauty (that commandeth Fate)
Her forehead where to keep her state;
Should another step in place,
I car'd not, I'de not love that face.
Imagine next her braine divine
Or mansion for the Muses Nine,
Did her bosome yeeld choice places
For the Charities and Graces;
Had she stately Juno's stile,
Pallas front, or Ʋenus smile.
If he enjoy her and not I:
For those vertues what care I.
Trac'd she loves Queen in her treasure,
And could teach the act of pleasure
Made Lais in her trade a fool,
Phrine or Thais set to Schoole:
To Helen read, or could she do
Worth Io and Europa too,
If these sweets from me she spare,
Ile count them toies, nor will I care.
But if my Mistresse constant bee,
And love none alive save me:
Be chast, although but something fair,
Her least perfection I'le think rare:
Her ile adore, admire, preferre,
Idolatrize to none but her,
When such an one I find and trie,
For her Ile care, Ile live, Ile die.

div.head: A Gentleman having attained the happinesse to have the possession of his Mistresse person in his Chamber (she though greatly affecting him, yet desiring to be thought exquisitely chast) may thus expresse himselfe in a Dialogue between Arnaldo and Olivia.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: SIr, if you judge me by this simple Action, by the outward habit and complexion of that easinesse it hath to your designe, you may with justice not onely call me woman, but strange woman; but when you shall be pleased to bring that concurrence of my fortune which but very lately you were pleased to urge, it may beget a thing at least resembling an excuse, though none like reason.

sp.speaker: Arnaldo.
sp.p: No, my dearest Mistresse, then surely Love hath none, nor beauty any, I thought that I had enough remov'd already all scruple from your brest, I rather now durst to perswade my self to shew you how that all commanding Love by his accesses growes more naturall, and now since Love hath the honour to approach these sister-swelling brests, and touch this soft and rosie hand, he hath the skill to draw their Nectar forth with kissing, and could make more wanton salts from this brave promontory downe to this valley, then the nimble Roe, could play the hopping sparrow about these netts, and sport like to a squirrell in these groves, bury himselfe in every Silkwormes Kell; that is here unravelled then run into the snare, every haire here being cast into a curle to catch a flying Cupid; deare Lady, please to withdraw with me to the next roome, a place that will more favour our embraces.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Good faith you make me pant.

sp.speaker: Arnaldo.
sp.p: Those blushes doe but add unto your beauty, (could it be capable of an addition) this height of happinesse shall ever bind mee in the bonds of gratitude—

lg.l: THen our musick is in prime,
When our teeth keep triple time;
Hungry notes are fit for Knells,
May lanknesse bee
No quest to mee,
The Bagpipe sounds, when that it swells.
A Mooting night brings wholsome smiles,
When John an Okes, and John a Stiles,
Doe grease the Lawyers Satten;
A reading day
Frights french away,
The Benchers doe speake Latin.
He that's full doth verse compose,
Hunting deales in Sullen prose;
Take notice and discard her,
The empty Spit,
Nere cherish'd wit,
Minerva Loves the Larder.
First to breakfast, then to dine,
Is to conquer Bellarmine.
Distinctions then are budding,
Numph Crouches wit,
Doth never hit
But after his bag-pudding

div.head:
THE RURALL ACADEMY, OR Instructions for (and the manner of) the Uulgar, intermingled with other more Facetious fancies. viz. Such as
Tom Tickle-foot.
Lawrence Clod.
Peter Puppie.
Meg of the Milke paile.
Francis of the Apple-loft.
Doll of the Darie, and such like.

AN AMOROVS DIALOGVE, Managed betweene
John Medlay a Tyler.
and Jone Simper-Sudds a Farmers Daughter.

sp.speaker: Medlay.
sp.p: NAy stay sweet Mistresse Joan, here are none but one friend (as thay zay) desires to speake, a cold word or two with you, how doe you veele your zelfe this frosty morning?

sp.speaker: Jone.
sp.p: What ha' you to do to aske I pray you, I am a cold.

sp.speaker: Medlay.
sp.p: It seemes you are hot good Mistresse Jone.

sp.speaker: Jone.
sp.p: You lie, I am as cold as yce, feele else.

sp.speaker: Medlay.
sp.p: Nay, you ha coold my courage, I am past, I ha' done feeling with you.

sp.speaker: Jone.
sp.p: Done with me, I doe defie you, so I doe, to say you ha' done with me.

sp.speaker: Medlay.
sp.p: Oh, you mistake, I meane not as you meane.

sp.speaker: Jone.
sp.p: Meant you not knavery?

sp.speaker: Medlay.
sp.p: Knavery say you, bring but dog that will say Iohn Medlay haz beat u'm, no, I am a Kyrsin soule, I take all the Hamlet to witnesse, if I were not begot in bashfulnesse, and brought up in shamefastnesse, bring but a Cat will sweare upon a booke, I ha' so much as zet a vier her taile; knavery quoth you?

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.p: Doe you love me then Iohn?

sp.speaker: Medlay.
sp.p: Harrow, Alass I swelt as I goe, brenning in Love of little Cupido, wee'll be marryed to morne, Ione.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.p: No hast Iohn to hang true volke, soft fire makes sweet malt.

lg.l: Yet Iohn cheere up the better leg avore,
This is a deede is once done and no more.

sp.speaker: Iohn.

lg.l: And then tis done vor ever as they zay,
Vor each man hath his houre, each dog his day.

sp.p:
Ile go get my Leatherne Doublet with long points new furbush't, & a paire of wispes to swaddle my legs,
for we mun daunce on that day zure, and who can daunce in boots.

lg.l: Hum drum I crie,
No whole oxe in a pie.

sp.p: And then my long sawsedge hose, with my hat turn'd up o'the leere side, wee'l have Rosemary and bayes to vill a bow-pot, and with the zame Ile trim that vorehead of my best vorehorse, weell hire Father Rosin and his two boyes for a day and a halfe, lze warrant thee chuck.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.p: Ene as you list good Iohn, I am all yours as they zay.

lg.l: COme to the bride another fit
Fairely, to our country wit.
But o'your best; let all the steele
Of back, and braines, fall to the heele.
And all the quicksilver i'the mine,
Run i'the foot veines and refine
Your fork-um, jerk-um to a dance,
Shall fetch the fidlers out of France.
With the fancies of high trol
Trol about the Bride-all Boll:
And divide the broad Bride-cake,
Round about the Brides stake.
MY Lady young Chaplaine could never arrive,
More then foure points or thereabout;
He propos'd fifteen, but was gravell'd at five,
My Lady stood up, and still preacht 'em out.
The Red-hatred vertues in number but foure,
With grief he remembred, for one was not
The habits Divine, not yet in our power,
Were faith, hope and (brethren) the third is fogot.
Sir Iohn was resolved to suffer a drench,
To furnish his Spirit, with better provision;
A Posset was made, by a Leviticall wench,
It was of the chamber-mayds own composition.
The milke it came hot from an Orthodox cow,
Ne'r rid by the Pope, nor yet the Popes Bull.
The heate of zeale boyled it — knowes how,
'Twas the milk of the word, beleeve it who will.
The ingredients were divers, and most of them new,
No vertue was Iudg'd in an ancient thing,
In the Garden of Leyden some part of them grew:
And some did our owne universities bring.
Inprimis two handfulls of long Digressions,
Well squeezed and prest at Amsterdam,
They cured Buchanans dangerous passions;
Each Grocers shop, now will afford you the same.
Two ounces of Calvinisme not yet refin'd,
By the better Physitians, not thought to be good,
But 'twas with the seale of a Conventicle sign'd;
And approv'd by the simpling Brotherhood.
One quarter of practicall piety next,
With an ounce and halfe of Histrio-mastix,
Two spoonfulls of T. C. confused text;
Whose close noted Ghost, hath long agoe past Stix.
The crumbs of comfort, did thicken the messe,
'Twas turnd by the frowne of a sowre fac'd brother;
But that you will say converts wickednesse,
And will serve for the one aswell as the other.
An Ell, London measure of tedious grace,
Was at the same time conceived and sayd;
'Twas eate with a spoon defild with no face,
Nor the Image of an Apostles head.
Sir Iohn after this could have stood down the Sun,
Dividing the Pulpit, and text with one fist,
The glasse was compell'd, still rubbers to run;
And he counted the fift Evangelist.

div.head: A Country Courtship, in a Dialogue, between Laurence Clod and Meg of the Milke-Paile.

sp.speaker: Lawrence.
sp.p: YE kind to others, but ye coy to me deft Mistress, whether then the cheese new prest, smoother then creame & softer then the curds, why start ye from me ere ye heare me tell my wooing errand, and what rents I have, large heards and pastures, Swine, Kine, o' my own? and though my nale be cammus'd, my lips thick, and my chin briffled, Pan great Pan was such, I am na' say, na' Incubus, na' changeling, but a good man that lives o' my own geere.

sp.speaker: Meg.
sp.p: Ize care not for such luggage.

sp.speaker: Lawrence.
sp.p: An hundred udders for the payle I have, that gi' me milke, and curds, that make me cheese, and for the mercatts twenty swarme of Bees.

Whilke all the Summer humme about the hive an aged oake, the King of all the field, with a broad beech that growes afore my doore, that mickle mast unto the Ferme doth yield, but bid me, and I will straight play to you, and make you melodie.

sp.speaker: Meg.
sp.p: By no meanes, ah to me all minstrelsie is yrksome as are you.

sp.speaker: Lawrence.
sp.p: Why scorne you me, because I am an herdsman and feed swine, I also am Lord of other geere, smooth Bawsons cub the young Grice of a Gray twa' tynie urshins, and this Ferret gay.

sp.speaker: Meg.
sp.p: Out on 'em, what are these?

sp.speaker: Lawrence.
sp.p: I gem 'em yee.

sp.speaker: Leg.
sp.p: Out on the fiend and thee, go take them hence, they fewmand all the claithes and prick my coates, hence with them limmer Lowne, thy vermine and thy selfe; thy selfe art one.

div.head: A SONG. Between two Lovers Sung in two parts.

lg.l: Hee. COme my sweet, whilst every strayn
Calls our Soules into the eare,
Where the greedy listing faine
Would turne into the sound they heare:
Least in desire,
To fill the quire,
Themselves they tie
To harmony,
Lets kisse, and call them back againe.
She. Now lets orderly convey
Our Soules into each others brest,
Where enterchanged let them stay,
Slumbring in a melting rest;
Then with new fire
Let them retyre,
And still present,
Sweet fresh content
Youthfull as the earthly day.
Hee. Then let us a tumult make,
Suffering so our Soules, that wee
Carelesse who did give or take,
May not know in whom they bee.
Then let each smother
And stifle the other,
Till we expire
In gentle fire,
Scorning the forgetfull lake.

div.head: A COMPLEMENTALL CONTESTATION. The Lover being unwilling to part with a late received token, which his Mistresse (seemingly) is very earnest to recover, which occasioneth a sublime dispute.
div.stage: A Dialogue (supposed) betweene Alberto and Sophrinda.

sp.speaker: Aberto.
sp.p: HE must be more the man that gaines it back without my will.

sp.speaker: Sophrinda.
sp.p: Your justice must restore it, doe you delight to tryumph with soft spoiles of a Ladies cabinet.

sp.speaker: Alberto.
sp.p: As I would not feigne favour, or belie a jewell, or a twist, to gaine the name of creature, or of a servant to any, so by your beauty (if I may sweare by that) where honour is transmitted in a true mysterious gage of an Immaculate mind, I will d • fend it as some sacred Relique, or some more secret pledge dropt downe from heaven, to guard me from the dangers of the earth.

sp.speaker: Sophrinda.
sp.p: But in that you make it common, you bereave it of all that you call divine.

sp.speaker: Alberto.
sp.p: He that vaunts of a received favour ought to bee punished as sacrilegious persons are, because hee violates that sacred thing called spotlesse honour, but it may be seen, and yet not prostitute, I would not smother my joyes and make my happinesse a stealth.

sp.speaker: Sophrinda.
sp.p: Your thoughts doe flatter your deceived fancie into a state, which when you leave to think, dies as your thoughts which kept it up, what is it, that you call joy and happiness.

sp.speaker: Alberto.
sp.p: I must confess I have no merits, whose just heart may extract ought from you called Love, yet when I doe consider that Affection cannot looke vertuously on any thing that is resplendent, but a subtile Image purely reflecting thence, must needs arise and pay that look againe, I doe take that leave to say, the carefull Deities provide that love shall ner'e be so unhappy as to want his brother.

sp.speaker: Sophrinda.
sp.p: Why, I never spent a sigh for you, you never had a kisse for the reversion of one yet.

sp.speaker: Alberto.
sp.p: Such Love is but Loves Idoll, and these soft tones that confine it to a kisse, or an embrace; doe as the superstitious did of old, contract the Godhead into a Bull or Goate, or some such lustfull creature; bee it farre from me to thinke that whensoever I see cleare streames of beautie, that I may presume to trouble them with quenching of my thirst, where a full spendour, where a bright effusion of immateriall Beames doe meet, for to make up one body of perfection, I should accompt my selfe injurious unto that Deity which hath let downe himselfe into those rayes, if that I should draw nigh without an awfull Adoration, which my religion payes to you, but being you like not the devotion, be content to slight the sacrifice, but spare the Altar.

sp.speaker: Sophrinda.
sp.p:
I am so farre from turning a beast, in which there lives a sparke of chaster honour, that I would hazzard
this so priz'd a trifle, which men call life, that I might live there still, and prove that Love is but an Engine of the carefull powers invented for the safety and preservation of afflicted goodnesse, conceive not hence a passion burning towards you, for she that speakes like woman can be resolv'd like man.

sp.speaker: Alberto.
sp.p: I can distinguish between Love and Love, between flames and good intents, nay between flames and flames themselves, the grosser now fly up, and now flie downe, still coveting new matter for food, consuming and consum'd, but the pure quicker flames that shoot up alwaies in one continued pyramid of lustre know no commerce with earth, but unmixt still, and still aspiring upwards (if that may be stil'd aspiring which is nature) have this property of immortality, still to suffice themselves, neither devowring nor yet devowred, which I acknowledge yours, on which I looke as on refin'd Ideas that knew no mixture or corruption being one eternall simpleness, that these should from the circle of their chaster glories, dart out a beame on me, is farre beyond all humane merit, and I may conclude, th • y have onely their owne nature for a cause, and that they are good, they are diffusive too.

sp.speaker: Sophrinda.
sp.p: Your tongue hath spoke your thoughts so nobly, that I should esteeme my selfe the curse of all my sex, should I not gratifie such worth with Love, I here proclaime my selfe, yours to dispose of.

sp.speaker: Alberto.
sp.p: And when I faile to manifest my gratitude, may Joves severest thunder strike me dead.

div.head: A Letter to a Mistresse, occasioned by a Dreame, (or at least if the Lover please to affirme so.)

lg.l: OR scorne, or pitty on me take,
I must the true relation make:
I am undone to night.
Love in a subtile dreame disguiz'd,
Hath both my heart and me surpriz'd;
Whom never yet he durst attempt t' awake,
Nor will he tell me for whose sake
He did me this delight
Or spite.
But leaves me to enquire,
In all my wild desire
Of sleep againe, who was his ayd,
And sleepe so guilty and afraid,
As since he dares not come within my fight.

closer.signed: Yours wholly E. C.

div.head: AN EPISTLE. (But not to be used till the late Act bee of no force.)
div.l: BY those eyes, at whose purer fires,
Love lights his torch, t'Inflame desires:
By your forehead whence he bends
His bow, and round his Arrowes sends;
By your haire, whose globy rings
He curles, and crispeth with his wings.
By your lips the banke of kisses,
Where men may plant and gather blisses.
Tell me, doe you love, or no,
That I may tell in verse tis so..
You blush, but friends are either none,
(Though counted bodies) or but one,
Ile aske no more, but bid you love,
That either may example prove
To other, and live patterns how
Others may love, as we doe now.
Slip no time, Time stands not still,
I know no faire one, else that will,
To use the present's no abuse,
Your husband, you make your excuse:
Nought injures him, hee's such an one
Would make himselfe (and that alone,)
That which we make him, in his wife,
His issue, and all things of life;
Because (forsooth) he will varie,
Hee's content — extraordinary.

div.head: A Country Woman schooling her Sonne For not prosecuting his Love, Ad Rem.
div.stage: A DIALOGVE, Between Mother Maudlin, and her Son Clod.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: SHe wish'd mee at the Dee'l with all my presents.

sp.speaker: Maudlin.
sp.p:
A tu luckie end, she wishend thee fowle Limmer d • ittie Lowne, gud faith it duills me that I am thy Mother, thou wooe thy Love, thy Mistress with twa hedgehoggs, a stink and Brooke, a polcat, out thou howlet, thou shouldst ha' gin her a madge owle
and then, tho' hadst made a present 'o thy selfe, Owle-spiegle.

sp.speaker: Cled.
sp.p: Why Mother I ha • heard you maund to geive as often as cause calls.

sp.speaker: Maudlin.
sp.p: I know well, it is a wittie part sometimes to give, but what, to whame; no monsters 'or to maydens, he shuld present them with mare pleasand things naturall, and what all women covet, to see the common parent of us all, which Mayds will twire at 'tween their fingers — with which his Syre gate him, hee, hee get another and so beget posterity upon her — this he should doe (false Gelden) gaining thy gait, and du thy turnes betimes, or I'is gar take thy new breikes fra thee, and thy du'let tu, the Talleur, and the Sowter shall undu all they ha' made, except thou manlier woo.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Gud moder if you chiude mee Ize doe wai • s.

sp.speaker: Maudlin.
sp.p: Hang thee, I gief thee, to the Devills eirs.

div.head: Two Gentlemen willing to paint forth some Letcherous old Crone. A Dialogue between Olyndro and Gioto.

sp.speaker: Olyndro.
sp.p: YOU do her too much honor to think shee deserves a thing that can lust moderately, give her the Sorrel Gelding in my Lords long stable.

sp.speaker: Gioto.
sp.p: Or the same colour'd brother which is worse.

sp.speaker: Olyndro.
sp.p: Her breath would rout an Army sooner then that of a Cannon.

sp.speaker: Gioto.
sp.p: It would lay a Devill sooner then all Tytremius Charmes.

sp.speaker: Olyndro.
sp.p: How her breath blusters in her nostrills, just like the wind in a fowle Chimney.

sp.speaker: Gioto.
sp.p: For her Gate, that is such as if her nose did strive to outrun her heeles.

sp.speaker: Olyndro.
sp.p: Her playster'd face doth drop against moist weather.

sp.speaker: Gioto.
sp.p: Which when she writes it, lookes just like a rufled boot.

sp.speaker: Olyndro.
sp.p: Or an old paper-Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Gioto.
sp.p: Her nose the candle in the midst of it.

sp.speaker: Olyndro.
sp.p: Sure the Surveyer of the High-waies will have to do with her, for not keeping her countenance passable.

sp.speaker: Gioto.
sp.p: There lies a hoar-frost on her head, and yet a constant thaw in her nose.

sp.speaker: Olyndro.
sp.p: She is like a piece of firewood dropping at one end, and yet burning in the midst.

sp.speaker: Gioto.
sp.p: You may hear her guts squeak like Kitlings.

sp.speaker: Olyndro.
sp.p: They must come to that within this two or three years, by that time she will bee a true perfect Cat, they practise before hand.

sp.speaker: Gioto.
sp.p: Nothing is left her that may stile her woman, but lust and tongue, no flesh but what the vices of the sex exact to keep them in heart.

sp.speaker: Olyndro.
sp.p: She is so lean, and out of—case, that 'twete absurd, to call her Devill incarnate.

div.head: The Consecration of a new Built Fabrick.
div.l: SAint Francis, and Saint Benedight,
Bless this houss from wicked weight;
From the Night-Mare, and the Goblin,
That is hight Goodfellow Robin.

div.head: AN ODE. In the praise of (the inward Endowments) some much meriting Mistrisse.

lg.l: THough beauty be the marke of praise,
And yours of whom I sing be such
As not the World can praise too much;
Yet is't your vertue now I raise.
A Vertue, like allay, so gone
Throughout your form, as though that move
And draw, and conquer all mens love,
This subjects you to love of one.
Wherein you tryumph; yet because
'Tis of your self, and that you use
The noblest Freedome, not to chuse
Against or faith, or honours Lawes.
But who should lesse expect from you
In whom alone, love lives agen,
By whom he is restor'd to men,
And kept, and bred, and brought up true.
His falling Temples you have rear'd,
The whither'd Garlands tane away,
His Altars kept from the decay
That Envie wish'd, and Nature fear'd.
As on them burne so chast a flame
With so much Loyalties expence,
Love to acquit such excellence,
Is gone himself into your name.
And you are he, the Deitie
To whom all Lovers are design'd,
That would their better Objects find,
Among which faithfull Troop am I.
Who as an offspring at your shrine
Have sung this Hymn, and here intreat
One sparke of your diviner heat
To light upon a love of mine.
Which if it kindle not but scant
Appear, and that to shortest view;
Yet give me leave t'adore in you
What I in her, am griev'd to want.

div.head: A SONG. On a Lady sleeping.
div.l: SEal up her eyes, O sleep, but flow
Mild, as her manners, to and fro,
Slide soft into her, that yet she
May receive no wound from thee.
And yee present her thoughts O Dreames,
With hushing winds, and purling streames,
Whiles hovering silence sits without,
Carefull to keepe disturbance out.
Thus seize her sleepe, thus her againe Resigne,
So was heavens gift, wee'l reckon thine.

div.head: SONG 2. On the same occasion.
div.l: SEE how the emulous Gods doe watch,
Which of them first her breath should catch;
Ambitious to resigne their blisse,
Might they but feede an Ayre like this:
Thus here protected she doth lie,
Hedg'd with a Ring of Majesty.
And doth make heaven all her owne,
Never more safe then when alone.
Thus while she sleepes Gods doe ascend and kisse,
They lend all other breath, but borrow this.

div.head: A LOVE-LETTER. The Lover relating a discourse betwixt himselfe and Cupid, in reference to his Mistresse.
div.l: DEarest Florinda, you alone that are
My better fortune, and my wished starre;
You who doe governe more my active blood,
Then silver Cynthia doth the raging flood:
Heare me what late discourse I had of you,
Beleeve it, the narration's very true.
Cupid, amongst my Muses finding mee,
By chance he hapned your name for to see,
Set to the Violl, in a ravishing straine,
Most sure, said he, if that I have a braine.
The Nymph here mentioned can be no other,
Then Paphos Queen, my lovely Sea-borne mother.
For so hath mighty Homer prais'd her haire,
And so hath smooth Anacreon drawne the ayr
Of her celestiall face, and made it rise
Iust to the lustre of her sparkling eyes:
Both her browes bent, and shaped like my Bow,
By her Diviner aspect I her know.
Those which you call my shafts, but looke and see,
You'l find, that they my mothers blushes bee.
Such as that sacred bath, your verse discloses
In her faire cheekes of milke, and fragrant Roses.
Nay more then this, this Goddesse very name
Comes neere my mothers, nay it is the same;
I doe confesse all this then I repli'd,
Witnesse that glass, that hangeth by the side;
That very girdle that surrounds her waste,
In all she Ʋenus is, save that shee's chaste.
But Cupid know this, beauty yet doth hide,
Some thing of greater worth then thou hast spide;
The outward grace tis true, weak love beguiles,
She is thy mothers selfe, when that she smiles;
But she is the true Juno, when she walkes,
