And quite out-strips Minerva when she talkes.

div.head: A Lovers Contemplation.
div.l: CAn Beauty that compeld me write,
Threat with those meanes, she did invite?
Did her imperfections make me gaze,
Then Love, and now would they amaze?
Was she good a farr off, but neere
A terror, or is this but feare?
As water makes things put in't, streight,
Crooked appear. So my conceipt
I can boldnesse help, Love sware
With Fortune, to help those that dare
But which shall lead me, both are blind,
Such Guides, they way can never find,
Except the way erre, to those ends
The best are still the blindest friends;
Now Lovers may mistake to think
Love, Fortune blind, when they but wink,
Or it may be, for truth and state
'Cause they would justice Imitate;
Vail their own eyes, Impartially
To bring us to our destinie;
If thus, come love, and Fortune go
I'le lead, or if my Fate will so
I must send first, my choice assignes
My breast to love, Fortune my lines.

div.head: COUNCEL.
div.l: DOings a pleasure bad and short,
We must streight repent us of the sport
Like Beasts, that onely know to do it,
Let's not rush blindly on unto it;
In time, that fervour will decay,
But thus perpetual holiday;
Let's close together, lie and kiss,
There's no toll, nor no shame in this;
This pleaseth and long will please, never
Decaies, but is beginning ever.

div.head: A Platonick Inter-locution (supposed) between Parismus and Placentia.

sp.speaker: Parismus.
sp.p:
FAirest of things, and onely like thy self, those pleasutes which the laden bosome of this lower world permits to carefull mortalls, are too grosse,
too earthy to be ours; let us mount the wings of our desires, and take a flight into Natures sincere Kingdome, where she mints, and shapes refin'd delights, delights like thee.

sp.speaker: Placentia.
sp.p: Wee'l to those places set apart for love, where Trees kisse trees, and Branch embraceth branch, Poplar to Poplar whispers there, and Myrtle to Myrtle doth figh to Myrtle; Flowers erect themselves, and boughs encline to meet them in salutes, with an unquestion'd freedome, no stalk being made yellow there by jealousie, no Tree whithering through sad suspition, that this Flower doth court that bough, or that bough serve this Flower.

sp.speaker: Parismus.
sp.p: O these are joyes fresh from the Dug of nature, there some plants shew, they have fire even in their colours, some Dialogues, make, and some more passionate grieve, sweet odours are their sighs, and dew their tears. Some leaves they say, have words of woe inscrib'd; as if that Flowers writ mutuall letters too, our antient Love-Priests say, that in that Garden a Rose, and Lillie (to whose sacred leaves the neighbouring Flowers do reverence) mingle roots, in a most streight embrace, and then produce Male Roses blanched, with the whitenesse of the Lillie, and Female Lillies dipt in the Roses blush, each borrowing others beauty, so that 'tis thought Nature prophesies of some future times which shall fulfil it and be happy.

sp.speaker: Placentia.
sp.p: As they are types of things to come, so too 'tis said, that antient stories are cut there in Trees, and the mysterious hedges are the Annals of former Ages, thus each thing contained something that may be read, doth make the whole but one fair volume to instruct blest foules.

sp.speaker: Parismus.
sp.p: But first my dear 'twere no Impietie for us to mingle limbs while here on earth.

sp.speaker: Placentia.
sp.p: For that, my womans temper not allowes I should encourage, or dehort you (dearest) our soules united are, our bodies then need no more happy union.

div.head: Hunting (alluding to love) the Noblest Exercise. A SONG.

lg.l: HUnting it is the Noblest exercise,
Makes men laborious, active, wise;
brings health, and doth the spirits delight,
It helpes the hearing and the sight.
It teacheth Arts, that never slip,
The memory, good horsemanship.

div.head: SONG. Sung by a Company of Cup-shaken Corybants.

lg.l: Now, now, the Sun is fled
Down into Thetis bed,
Ceasing his solemn course a while,
What then?
'Tis not to sleep but be
Merry all night as wee.
Gods can be made sometimes as well as men.
Then laugh we, and quaffe untill our rich noses
Grow red, and contest with our Chaplets of Roses.
If he be fled, whence may
We have a second day
That shall not set till we command,
Here see.
A day that does arise
Like his, but with more eyes,
And warmes us, with a better fire then hee.
Then laugh we, and quaffe untill our rich noses
Grow red, and contest with our Chaplets of Roses.
Thus then we chase the night,
With these true floods of light.
This Lesbian wine which with it's sparkling streams
Darting diviner graces,
Cast's glories round our faces.
And dulls the Tapers majestique beames.
Then laugh we and quaffe we untill our rich noses
Grow red, and contest with our Chaplets of Roses.

div.head: A BLESSING BESTOWED VPON THE BANTLING OF A BROWNIST.

lg.l: NOw thou our future Brother,
That hast tane forme from thy mother;
Spring up, and Dods blessing on't,
Show thy little sorrill pate,
And prove regenerate,
Before thou be brought to the font.
May the Parish Surplice bee
Cut in peeces quite for thee,
To wrap thy soft body about,
So t'will better service doe,
Reformed thus into
The state of an Orthodox clout.
When thou shalt leave the Cradle,
And shalt begin to wadle,
And trudge in thy little Apron,
Mayst thou conceive a grace
Of halfe an houres space,
And rejoyce in thy friday Capon.

l.hi: For an error that's the Flocks,

lg.l: Name Mr. Paul, but urge St. Knox:
And at every Reformed Dinner,
Let ch • ese come in and preaching,
Confirme an unsatisfi'd sinner;
Thence grown up to hate a Ring,
And deifie an offering.
And learne to sing what others say,
Let Christs tide by thy fast,
And Lent thy good repast,
And regard not an Holy day.

l.hi: Mayst thou talke thou knowst not what,
And be a prettie prick-eard Brat.

div.head: The presentation of a Sylke Hood.
div.l: SO Love appear'd breaking his way,
When from the Chaos he b • ought Day,
Drawne from the tender bud, so shewes
The halfe-seen glory of the Rose,
As you when veyl'd, and I may sweare
(Viewing your beauty) buddeth there,
Such doubtfull life had groves, where Rods
And twigs, at last did shoote up Gods,
When shade then darkneth the face,
May I not reverence the place.
Accept this vaile then (sweete) for I
Affect a clouded Deitie.

lg.l: TEll me no more of minds embracing minds,
And hearts exchang'd for hearts;
That Spirits Spirits meete as winds doe winds,
And mix their subt'lest parts:
That two unbodied essences may kisse,
And then like Angels twist and feele one blisse.
I was that silly thing that once was wrought,
To practise this thin Love;
I climbd from sex to soule, from soule to thought.
But thinking there to move,
Headlong I rowl'd from thought to soule and then,
From soule I lighted at the Sex agen.
As some strict down-look'd men pretend to fast,
Who yet in closets eate:
So Lovers, who protest they Spirits tast,
Feede yet on grosser meate.
I know they boast they soules to soules convey,
How ere they meet, the body is the way.
Let all beleeve this truth that those that tread
Those vaine Aeriall waies,
Are like young Hares and Alchymists misled,
To wast their wealth and daies,
For searching thus to be for ever Rich,
They only finde a medicine for the itch.

div.head: A Complement all Rhapsody, Meriting presentation to any Noble Mistresse, the Lover desirous to illustrate the Beatitude of the (feigned) Elyzium.
div.l: FOr that our hearts to Loves soft pleasure yeelds,
Love shall conduct us to th'Elyzian Fields;
Among those pleasures we shall walke and see,
Here some Gyrle dallying, on her Lovers knee.
Weaving what caught her heart into a net,
Another into a twisted Anulet
Of fagrant flowers, dancing before her D • are,
Presenting all the pleasures of the yeare.
There others making Dialogues with sighs
In a sad parly, wooing with their eyes,
Garlands and Nosegaies int' Epistles framd,
There others sleeping (with late actions tam'd)
There with a bough of Myrtle one doth guard
His sleeping Mistresse, taking his reward
Oft from her Rosie lips, while others runne
(In a dissembled anger) as to shunne
Their zealous votaries, and at each turne,
Fling Violets in their faces, here forlorne
His Armes a-crosse a pensive Lover sits
And raves, and smiles and teares his face by fits;
Till in conclusion he desert his mone,
Grasping the slender wast of's loved one;
Queene of the Kingdome, in a chaire of light,
Thou shalt enthroned be (my deare delight)
While Doves with oynted wings o're thee shal hover,
An hourely tribute payd thee by each Lover
As a due homage, each upon his Knee,
Offering his heart, to be dispos'd by thee.
Fountaines shall walke upon thy table, and
Birds singing to the waters fall shall stand
In crowds together on Ambrosiac Trees,
Drawing the Spheres downe with their melodies,
And by the marriage of their mingled sounds,
Make the three Syrens sleepe, the charmed grounds
Yeelding both Myrrhe and Cassia, every where,
The bounteous soyle shall blushing Roses beare.
All this (my dearest) doubt not to enjoy
Hereafter, if thou here wilt sport and toy.

div.head: A Sportive Complementall Interlocution (The Adolescent being willing for ever to frustrate her hopes whom he hath (seemingly) assented to Marry) A Dialogue supposed betweene JVƲENILLIO and THAIS.

sp.speaker: Juvenillio.
sp.p: HOw now, so melancholy sweete.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: How could I chuse, being thou wert not here, the time is come I hope now, that thou wilt be as good unto me as thy word.

sp.speaker: Juvenillio.
sp.p: Nay, hang me if ere I repent, you will take mee both wind and limbe at the venture, will you not?

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Yes good chuck every inch of thee, shee were no woman that would not.

sp.speaker: Iuvenillio.
sp.p: I must tell you one thing, and yet I am loth.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Pray thee tell me.

sp.speaker: Juvenillio.
sp.p: Why then Ile tell you sweet, I was not borne with it I confesse, but lying in Turky with a late Embassadour (one of whose meniall traine I boast my selfe) the great Turke somewhat suspitious of mee lest I might entice some of his Seraglio, did command I should be forthwith cut.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: A heathen deed it was; none but an Infidell could have the heart to doe it.

sp.speaker: Juvenillio.
sp.p: Now you know the worst of me, that you must trust to; come let us to Church.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Good sir excuse me, nature never intended one woman should be joyned to another, the holy blessing of wedlock was increase and multiply, I will doe nothing against Gods word, and therefore I here release you of your promises.

sp.speaker: Iuvenillio.
sp.p: Since you needs will cast east me off; let me intreate this one thing of you, that you would not make me your table-talke at the next Gossipping.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Never feare it, indeed I pittie thee, poore thing, or rather poore Nothing, I shall get you a contribution (perhaps) of the women of the Parish next Sunday, farewell poore maim'd man.

div.head: TRACT. 3. EPIST. 10. The Lover finding that his Mistresses affections are solely his, and that the obstinacy of her parents alone obstructs the fruition of his joyes, may thus Epistolize.
div.p: BEcause thy Parents gave thee flesh, must they therefore tyrannize over thy soule; indeed had they produc'd thee without sinne, could they assure the state of the next life, and as they have begotten regenerate thee; there were no reason but thou shouldst place thy affection where they please, in hope, that either for thy sufferance, thou should'st have future reward, or not thriving in thy endeavours, they should assuredly bear the blame: I confesse Children owe much, and a great debt is due to Parents; yet if Heaven have not allotted them so much power as to challenge the lives they gave, how much lesse then should they become so tyrannous, as to take from them that high prized Jewel of liberty in choice, whereon depends the main contentment that Heaven can possibly afford. Well, since it is so, that there is no hope we shall ever accrew the assent of thy obdurate Parents (my Dear Dear) let us resolve that we have the suffrage of Heaven (where undoubtedly all Mariages are decreed, ere they are consummated on earth) and (clandestinly) incorporate our selves; since I find it is impossible fot me to preserve my soule in flesh any longer with out thy societie.

closer.signed: thou knowest I am thine and thine only, G. K.

lg.l: HAd I a Mistresse some do think
She would revealed be,
And I would favours wear and drink
Her health upon my knee.
Alas poor fooles, they aime awry,
Their fancie flaggs too low;
Could they my loves rare course espy,
They would amazed grow.
Then ere my eyes betray me shall
Ile swell and burst with pain,
And for each drop that they let fall
My heart shall bleed me twain.
For since my soule more sorrow bears
Then common Lovers know,
I scorn my passion should like theirs
A common humor show.

div.head: EPIST. 11. One friend (merily) certifies another of the causelesse jealousie of one of their acquaintance, containing the lively description of a jealous coxcomb.
div.p:
SHould you associate your friend C. B. at Table, you could not chuse but laugh heartily (as my selfe have done) to see what notice the jealous woodcock takes of his wives words, and looks in what a fear he eats his meat, what superstitious signes he makes, how he nods and winks with twenty
scurvy gestures; though the timorous soule cannot render you the least cause of his suspition; now some have cause enough, and such seem to have colour for their distemperature; though there's little reason for any man to strive to retain that which will needs away: to seek to restrain a womans will, is but beating the wind, and he that strives to doe it, deserves to be incorporate of their societie who strove to hedge in the Cuckow. Why should a man put himselfe to pain (as some have done) to faigne businesse, and then at night lurk about his habitation? where, be it but the stirring of a mouse, he takes strict notice of it, and what greater madnesse then so to doe? for if thereby he make a discovery of any thing amiss, the greatest good that he shall get thereby is more vexation to prey upon his mind; for then the mischief that before he but fear'd, he is certain of now, and need doubt it no more: and is not that a goodly reward think you, this is honest C. B's case, and truly I pittie him, for on my soule his wife is truly chast: I intreat you (for I know you have much power over him) to endeavour all you can to eject this devill out of him, which is all I have to say, save that I am

closer.signed: Your friend in all service, T. L.

lg.l: HEr dainty Palme I gently prest,
And with her lip I plaid,
My cheek upon her panting breast
And on her neck I layd;
And yet we had no sense of wanton lust,
Nor did we then mistrust.
With pleasant toyle we breathlesse grew
And kiss'd in warmer blood,
Vpon her lips the honey dew
Like drops of Roses stood.
And on those flowers plaid I the busie Bee
Whose sweets were such to mee.
But kissing and embracing we
So long together lay,
Her touches all enflamed me,
And I began to stray.
My hands presum'd so farre, they were too bold,
My tongue unwisely told.

div.head: EPIST. 12. The Lover having gained the goodwill of his loved one, but finding some obstruction, for that his estate is not equall to hers (the occasion why her friends endeavoured to break the match) may send this letter to his Mistresse.
div.l: ALthough unequall in degree and worth,
And that our fortunes different be brought, forth.
Say that which I dare call my owne were not,
The want of wealth cannot dissolve our knot.
We are contracted, which is much at one
As if the Church had made our union.
Marriage was not ordain'd to enrich men by
Unlesse it were in their posteritie:
And they that doe for other causes wed
Nere knew the true sweets of a Marriage Bed;
Nor shall they by my will, for 'tis unfit
They should have blisse that never aym'd at it.
Though that bewitching gold the rabble blinds,
And is the object of all vulgar minds:
Yet those me thinks that graced seem to be
With so much good as doth aprear in thee:
Should scorn their better taught desires to tie
To that which fooles doe get their 'honour by.
I can like of the wealth (I must confesse)
Yet more I prize the maid, though monylesse.
One body I will never daign to make
With her I loth for her possessions sake;
Nor wish I ever to have that mind bred
In me, that is in those, who when they wed
Think it enough they do attain the grace
Of some new honour, or some golden place.
But I am too prolix, my jealous care
Of thee [lest fate be constant to my fear]
Makes me so verbal (dearest) thee and I
I see our selves must knit the Gordian tie,
Maugre the frownes of friends, let's give our hands,
And afterwards discourse of coine and lands.

closer.signed: Which is the ardent desire of (dearest) your passionate Lover, and zealous Servitor, M. S.

lg.l: I Wandred out awhile agone,
And went I know not whither;
By chance rare beauties many a one
Were in a knot together.
Like two fair Suns two beauties bright,
I shining saw together;
And tempted by their double light
My eyes I fixt on either.
Such equall sweet Dame Venus gave,
That I preferr'd not either;
And when for love I thought to crave
I knew not well of whether
But seeing my divided heart
In chusing knew not whether,
Love angry grew, and did depart,
And now I care for neither.

div.head: EPIST 12. A Maid or Widow being forsaken by him, who once protested entire affection to her, may thus divulge her grief by Letter.
div.p:
I Know had I been false or wavering in my faith, thou wouldst have shown thy selfe highly invective against women, and if in me it had heen an Error, shall it be thought no sinne in thee? rather I hold that that which is a blot to my reputation, would die thine with the deepest tincture of infamie, because nature hath ordained thee more vigorous, and therefore more able to endure a wrong: But it is the fatalitie of our sex, that you have the sole predominancy, and the care and burthen only is ours. You saw that at first I let in pitty, then approbation, and when I might have scorn'd thy love (as now thou despisest my affection) I entertain'd it among the inmost Angles of my breast: if thou canst excuse this treacherie, it must be with the aide of some more potent thing then reason. Perfidious man, be assured that heaven will not wink at
thy treachery, to whose justice I surrender thee, desiring whilst I am mortall to remain,

closer.signed: Thy worst enemy, VV. G.

div.head: A mayd or widow being forsaken, may thus certifie her false friend by Letter.

lg.l: OH false and perjur'd man,
whose lust hath no satietie,
Since nothing please thee can
Save changes and varietie.
O thou alone,
Constant to none,
In nothing setled save impietie.
Our sex why dost thou blame,
Tearm women sole offenders:
Tis you that's past all shame
Are still your own commenders.
That care nor fear
to whom you swear,
Cease judging and be now suspenders.
Phillis was chast and faire,
Demophoon false and cruell,
Sappho thought Phaon rare,
And he tearm'd her his jewell.
But traytors they
Their loves betray,
Poor we can oft foresee, but not eschew ill.
Falser then either, thou
As fowly hast betraid me
But ile beware thee now,
As heaven I hope shall aid me.
All thy procurements,
And sly allurements
Henceforth shall never more perswade me,
Thy oathes I hold as lyes,
I scorne thy crafty smiling,
Thy shape a meer disguise,
Thy practise but beguiling,
All thy protests,
As scoffes and jests,
And thy fair words no better then reviling.
Poysons Ile think thy kisses,
And from mine keepe thee fasting,
Thy torments count as blisses,
Thy breathing feare as blasting;
And thanke my fate
I now can hate,
Thee whom I now Abandon everlasting.

closer.signed: Which is the firme and unalterable resolution of her whose curses shall ever attend thee till they sink thee. M. K.

lg.l: FOr Loves sake kisse me once againe,
I long and should not beg in vaine.
Heres none to spie or see,
Why doe you doubt or stay?
Ile tast as lightly as the Bee;
That doth but touch his flower and flies away.
Once more and faith I will be gone,
Can he that Loves aske lesse then one.
Nay, you may erre in this,
And all your bounty wrong,
This could be called but halfe a kisse,
What w'are but once to doe we should doe long.
I will but mend the last and tell,
Where, how it would have relish'd well;
Joyne lip to lip, and try,
Each suck others breath.
And whilst our tongues perplexed lie,
Let who will think us dead or wish our death.

div.head: A Letter Pacificatorie, the Lover having rashly incurr'd his Mistresse displeasure, &c.
div.p:
I Confesse my selfe broke to my vowes, oathes, and all I had that might savour of credit, so that I am now driven almost to desperation, and must of necessity commit some outrage upon my selfe, for such a sadnesse as hath seized upon me, seldome or never appoacheth save to kill; offended Mistresse, you alone can lend succour, and force back this furie, you are yet so lovely, as that a light breakes from you which affrights Despaire her selfe, and fills my powers with a perswading hope, that you should be too noble to destroy where it is in your power to save: if there be nothing in me you can perceive worthy your grace and pardon, spare your owne goodnesse yet, and be not great in will and power, onely to exercise on God and goodnesse, the ignorant and fooles are onely pittilesse, but it is Godlike to forgive and save; I will not stand to justifie my fault, or lay my excuse upon the wind, nor bee niggardly in confessing my crime, or by naming my company, indeavour to countenance my vice as if I would urge Authority for sinne: no, I will stand arraigned and cast, that so I may become the subject of your clemencie, and may have just cause to acknowledge my selfe your Mercies Creature, resolving for the future, to live more your honour, then before your disgrace, thinke me man Mistresse, thinke
it was frailety, where weakeness offends, and piety is penitent, there greatnesse takes a glory to relieve, think that I was once yours, or at least againe may be, and that nothing can be vile that is a part of you; I am regenerate now, and become the child, of your compassion, bee pleased therefore to remit this one fault, and for expiation thereof, command me thousands of services, which alone can make happy,

closer.signed: Your dejected servant, E. L.

lg.l: VVHiles early light springs from the skies,
A fairer from your Bride doth rise,
A brighter day doth thence appeare,
And make a second morning there,
Her blush doth shed,
All ore the bed,
Clean shamefac'd beames,
That spreads in streames,
And purple round the modest aire.
I will not tell what shreekes and cryes,
What angry dishes and what ties,
What pretty oathes (then newly borne)
The listening Taper heard there sworne;
Whiles froward shee,
Most peevishly
Did yeelding fight
To keepe ore night,
What shee'd have profferd you ere morne.
Faire, we know, maids doe refuse
To grant what they doe come to lose,
Intend a conquest you that wed,
They would be chastly ravished.
Not any kisse
From Mistresse Cis,
If that you doe,
Perswade and wooe.
Know pleasures by extorting fed.
Oh may her armes wax black and blew,
Onely by hard encircling you,
May she round about you twine,
Like the easie twisting vine.
And whilst you sip,
From her full lip
Pleasures as new
As morning dew;
Let those soft ties your hearts combine.

div.head: THE ELEGANT AMAZON, Fighting in the vindication of her selfe and her and whole sex, against the whole race of mankind, who tax them of inconstancy.
div.l: HAng up those dull and envious fooles,
That talke abroad of womans change,
We were not bred to sit on stooles,
Our proper vertue is to range.
Such as in valour would excell,
Doe change (though man) and often fight,
Which we in Love must doe aswell,
If ever we will love aright
Nor is't inconstancy to change,
For what is better or to make,
(By searching) what before was strange.
Familiar for the uses sake,
And this profession of a store
In love doth not alone helpe forth
Our pleasures, but preserves us more
Familiar for the uses sake.

div.head: ANOTHER.
div.l: TAke change away, you take our lives,
Wee are no women then but wives;
The frequent varying of the deed
Is that which doth perfection breed.
The good from bad is not descri'd
But as 'tis often vext and tr • 'd:
For were the worthiest woman curst
To love one man hee'd leave her first.

div.head: AN ODE.
div.l: TO walk and rest, to live and die
And yet not know whence, how, or why
To have our hopes with fears still checked,
To credit doubts, and truths suspect.
This, this is that we may
A lovers absence say.
Follies without, are cares within,
Where eyes doe faile, their souls begin.

div.head: DIALOGUE 4. The second onset that the lover gives to his Mistresse, a Dialogue (supposed) between Anaphill, and Artesia.

sp.speaker: Anaphill.
sp.p:
FAith (Lady) you might certainly conclude me neer of kin to the Leveret, if I should abandon
my hold for a blast of breath, the repulse I lately received from your faire selfe, hath rather animated, then disconsolated me, love enjoynes me, and affection commands me once more to dare my destiny, and to implore you would be pleased to commiserate him, who if (for ever appointed to be) destitute of your deified substance, is for ever lost.

sp.speaker: Artesia.
sp.p: Sir, you are Master of a very confident spirit, did I not resolve the last time I saw you, that I wanted a will to wed; or were I desirous of a Husband, you (of all men) were most incapable of my embraces.

sp.speaker: Anaphill.
sp.p: I confesse (Lady) at that time, you were every jot as cruell as your selfe reports; but since I have entred into strict scrutiny with my selfe, and can discover no cause that might make you so averse, unlesse (paradoxically) you conceit it a crime to make a reall expression of an in-expressible love.

sp.speaker: Artesia.
sp.p: Alas (Sir) your qualifications want strength enough to captivate my faculties, you had need put your selfe to the expence of three years time in conning ore the Academy, or in getting shake-spears, Venus and Adonis by heart: he that I affect must be at once both Orator and Poet, Demosthenes and Ovid must be out-done by him, or it will prove an Herculean labour to arrest my resolutions.

sp.speaker: Anaphill.
sp.p: I must confesse I want the Frenchmans oily phrase, as much as the Spaniards froathie Bravadoes; yet (Lady) I should injure truth, should I say that I wanted sense, understood not men and manners, and sometimes knew not how to declaim with Tullie, as well as to Poetize with Tibullus.

sp.speaker: Artesia.
sp.p: Well (Sir) you shall give me time to summon my senses, to debate awhile with my reason, affection, and will: I shall shortly give you their resolves.

sp.speaker: Anaphill.
sp.p: I shall expect with patience—your humblest creature.

div.head: SIX MERRIE MAVNDERS: OR, THE (NEW) BEGGARS SONG.
The first.
div.l: LOrdly Gallants, tell me this
In your greatnesse, what one blisse
Have you gain'd that I enjoy not
(Though my safe content you weigh not.)

div.head: The second.
div.l: You have Lands lie here and there,
But my wealth is every where;
And this addeth to my store,
Fortune cannot make me poor,

div.head: The third.
div.l: Shee I love hath all delight
Rosie-red, and Lilly-white:
And who ere your Mistresse be
Flesh and blood as good as she.

div.head: The fourth.
div.l: To your selves you wise appear,
But alas deceived you are:
You doe foolish me esteem
And are that which I do seem.

div.head: The fifth.
div.l: That in which my pleasures be
No man can divide from me
And my care it addes not to,
What ere others say or doe.

div.head: The sixth.
div.l: You to please your sences feed,
But I eat good blood to breed:
And am most delighted than
When I spend it like a man.

div.head: CHORVS.
div.l: If you boast that you may gain
The respect of high-born beauties:
know we never wooe in vaine,
Nor ere scorned are our duties.
Therefore our despised power,
Greater is by farre then your:
And what ere you think of us,
They'r most happy that live thus.

div.head: A sportive complementall Colloquie (for the solace of the reader, (supposed) between Didaco and Mamilla.

sp.speaker: Didaco.
sp.p: FAirest of all things, will you eat a piece of Ginger-bread.

sp.speaker: Mamilla.
sp.p: You might have better manners, or at least more civilitie, then to scoffe her that never injur'd you.

sp.speaker: Didaco.
sp.p: Indad I love you, I vow I burn in love like some penny faggot.

sp.speaker: Mamilla.
sp.p: Saint Winifrid forbid it.

sp.speaker: Didaco.
sp.p: And I shall blaze out sir reverence, if you do not quench me.

sp.speaker: Mamilla.
sp.p: May I credit it?

sp.speaker: Didaco.
sp.p: Credit it? may I never eat more else.

sp.speaker: Mamilla.
sp.p: Though I say it that should not, I am affected towards you strangely, there's a thing comes each night to my beds head, every jot as swarthy, and much resembling thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Didaco.
sp.p: And to me every morning a voice utters these words, Matrimony, Matrimony, Didaco.

sp.speaker: Mamilla.
sp.p: Now God forbid it.

sp.speaker: Didaco.
sp.p: Then do I shake all over, but I beleeve it is some spirit that would joyne us.

sp.speaker: Mamilla.
sp.p: Goodly, goodly, may I beleeve this also?

sp.speaker: Didaco.
sp.p: What? not beleeve Don Didaco Doloso. Lady, I am wholly entirely yours, yea more, your Servants Servant.

sp.speaker: Mamilla.
sp.p: Me thinks you contradict your selfe, how can you be wholly mine, and yet my Servants Servant?

sp.speaker: Didaco.
sp.p: I doe but complement in that, if thou canst love, I can love too, law thee there now, I am rich.

sp.speaker: Mamilla.
sp.p: I use not to look after riches, 'tis the person that I aime at.

sp.speaker: Didaco.
sp.p: That's me, I am proper, handsome, faire, clean-limb'd, I am rich.

sp.speaker: Mamilla.
sp.p: I must have one that can direct and guide me, a Guardian rather then a Husband, for I am foolish, yet.

sp.speaker: Didaco.
sp.p: Now see the luck on't Lady, I am so too, I faith.

sp.speaker: Mamilla.
sp.p: Who ere hath me, will find me to be one of those things which his care must reforme.

sp.speaker: Didaco.
sp.p: Doe not doubt that I have a head for reformation, this nodle here shall doe it. I am rich.

sp.speaker: Mamilla.
sp.p: Riches create no love, I fear you take me for formality only.

sp.speaker: Didaco.
sp.p: Do not think I have any plots or projects in my head, I will doe any thing for thee that thou canst name or think on.

sp.speaker: Mamilla.
sp.p: By my virginity, I fear you'l flinch.

sp.speaker: Didaco.
sp.p: By my virginity (which is as good as yours I am sure) by my virginity, if we men have any such thing (as we men have such a thing) I will not flinch.

sp.speaker: Mamilla.
sp.p: My desire is then, that for the time to come you shall not so much as cast a sheeps eye upon any woman save my selfe.

sp.speaker: Didaco.
sp.p: If I look upon any but your sweet selfe, may I lose one of mine, marry Ile keep the other howsoever.

sp.speaker: Mamilla.
sp.p: I know not how I may beleeve you.

sp.speaker: Didaco.
sp.p: Blind me good now with this handkerchief, let me have but any reasonable thing to lead me home, I do not care though it be a dog, so that he knowes the way, or hath the wit to enquire it.

sp.speaker: Mamilla.
sp.p: Well Sir, ile take your own word. Farewell.

div.head: THE MARRIAGE. The Bride comming out of her Chamber.

lg.l: SEE the bride in all parts rare,
Full ripe for man (by Venus care)
Her face chast, like to her attyre,
Her modest blushes kindle fire:
Within her cheek, which by degrees
Growes hot, and warmes all that she sees.
The youths dispersed here and there,
Move swift to see this starre appear:
With such refulgence on each hand
Old men and aged Matrons stand:
Making a lane for her to passe,
While they think on the time that was.
Their youth, their strength, now gone and wasted,
And Nuptiall sweets which they have tasted.
On she goes, by the armes her lead
Two Ganymedes wheresoere she tread.
The eatth would have her to insist,
As loath to part with what she kist.
Still she proceeds upon the way,
While Zephire with her locks doth play;
And Boreas once again turn'd lover,
Blowes off her vaile for to discover
So rare a beautie, and dare swear
A new Orythia doth appear.
Thus was Argive Hellen seen,
Meant by Menelaus for his Queen.

div.head: The Bridegrooms first appearing.
div.l: SEE now the gates are opened wide,
From whence the Bridgroom towards the Bride,
Doth issue his soft tender skin,
Nere Rasor felt his budding chin:
Nought save purest down can show
His Mantle he ore him doth throw.
Love troubles whiles she waits him still.
Now entring he doth gaze his fill,
Feasts his eyes on his soveraign blisse,
Which done, they doe embrace and kisse.

div.head: The Nuptiall song at their returne from the Temple.

stage.l: The Mothers then with more then common care
Make businesse and bestirre them, who prepare
To lead them to their rest, whom as they bring
Near to the Chamber door the Quires thus sing.

div.l: MOst faire, most chast and meriting Bride,
Like to your Lord, to sports untride
Apply your selves, oh may your sheets
Abound with all delicious sweets.
Let Lucina when her childing growes
Release her from her painfull throwes.
Fruitfull as th'vine, let Bacchus fill
Her cup with juices that distill
From his choice Grapes: best of mankind
Your sexes pride, oh may you find
Daies of joy shortned nights of rest,
May you for ever live thrice blest
In your fair issue; y'are happy then,
Hark, unto this fates cry Amen.

lg.l: BEhold the Bed with all things fit,
On the side thereof a while they sit
Alone, they talk, they toy, and smile,
She, while she can, Time doth beguile;
Vntill her cheeks are all bewept,
To lose what she so long hath kept.
She casts her eyes oft on the place
Where shee's to wrestle, hides her face,
Nor dares she for to enter in,
Doubting what's lawfull is a sin:
He gently doth compell the lasse
As she were not of flesh but glasse.
Loth for to hurt her, yet he throwes
Her softly down, and near her growes.
Venus doth teach them a new trade,
The Marriage Queen is Chamber-maid:
Juno her selfe officious grown
Attend, to teach them Warres unknown.
He seeks for Babies in her eyes,
And feeles her Ivory breasts that rise
Like two white hills, and still doth praise
All that he touches, and thus saies.
Oh flourishing Virgin now my Bride,
Ya're grown at length thus near my side:
Of all my hopes the only treasure,
My long expected, latest pleasure.
My dearest Wife, this cou'd not be
But by the Almightie Powers decree.
And will you now Loves power withstand?
At this she staies his forward hand,
Trembling to think what's to ensue,
Or prove the thing she never knew:
She seems entranc'd and prostrate lies,
No word to utter nor no eyes
To see, she winks and lyeth still,
He must, and let him act his will.
'Twixt them they quench their amorous fires,
She hath her fears, he his desires.

div.head: EPIST. 13. The Lover not having time or opportunity to advertise his Mistresse (in person) that on such a day, he (with some others) shall desire her company, &c. may thus certifie her.
div.p: (TO prevent thy surprisall unawares) I held my selfe obliged to give thee notice, that on Wensday next, my selfe (heaven knowes against my mind, but I dare not deny) with some certain Princoxes, and their pliant Paranymphs, shall take a journey to Hogsden, to solace our selves, and make experiment what accommodation the Town affords. I presume to assure my selfe that I shall not be a cypher (as without thy person I must needs prove) and they in full numbers; therefore be pleased to gratifie my (bounden) service with this high favour, to adjourn vvhat ever employment thou hast destinated for that day, vvhich shall (if it be possible) yet further confirm me

closer.signed: Your humblest Servant, G. S.

lg.l: I Doe scorn to vovv a dutie,
Where each lustfull lad may wooe;
Give me her vvhose Sun-like beauty
Buzzards dare not soare unto.
Proud shee seem'd in the beginning,
And disdain'd my looking on t
But that coy one in the winning,
Proves a true one being wonne.
Therefore know when I enjoy one
(And for love employ my breath)
Shee I court shall be a coy one,
Though I winne her with my death.
Hee's a fool that basely dallies,
Where each Peasant mates with him.
Shall I haunt the thronged vallies
Whilst there's noble hills to clime?
Leave me then you Syrens, leave me,
Seek no more to work my harmes:
Crafty wiles cannot deceive me,
Who am proof against your charmes.

div.head: TRACT 4. EPIST. 14. A Maid (or Widow) being forsaken by him, who she once thought affected her dearly; and being resolved to sleight his neglect, may thus certifie him by letter.
div.p:
IT was a happy time, and was well with me; before I was bewitcht by thy Syrenical allurements: never Maid enjoyed more sweet content; the melody I used was free, and such as that pretty makes,
Whom never hand did seize upon, I remember I could then reade over the politick contrivances, and subtle stratagems of men, to betray our silly sex, how they would sigh, look sad, protest and swear, yea feign to die, when they never felt so much as the slender touch of worthy love; all which revolving in my mind, I made a vow (the generall humor of our sex) that never any mans complaint, or his fair tongue, should move my heart to liking; but who can promise to themselves an unalterable progresse in their resolves, I have infringed my oath, beleev'd and lik'd at once, yea so farre had I proceeded, that (till within these few daies) I saw not how so much as to hope a freedome. But now perfidious man) know, that as I am sensible of thy treacherous levitie, so I shall never be wonne (hadst thou the worlds treasure at thy command) to accept of thy societie; I have found my Error, and recovered my trewant senses, so that I am novv.

closer.signed: My own (next heaven) at command S. E.

lg.l: VVHy doe I fondly vvast my youth
In secret sighs and tears?
Why to preserve a spotlesse truth
Tast I so many cares?
For woman that no worth respect
Do so ingratefull prove,
That some shall winne by their neglect
What others lose with love.
VVAst I that nere did bow
In any servile dutie,
And shall I be made now
A Slave to Love and beauty?
Doe not Poor heart depend
On those vain thoughts that fill thee;
They'l fail thee in the end,
So must thy passions kill thee.
What ere she doe protest,
When fortunes doe deceive me;
Then she with all the rest
I fear alas will leave me.

div.head: AN ODE.
div.l: ONe frowne though but in jest,
Would rob me of my rest.
O rather now ile die,
'Twere worse then death if I,
Whilst I thus gentle find her,
Should find she proves unkinder.

lg.l: IN her eyes I find
Such signes of pitty moving:
Shee cannot be unkind
Nor erre, nor fail in loving.
And on her forehead this
Seemes written to relieve me,
My heart no joy shall miss
That Love or she can give me.
Which if I find, I vow
My service shall persevere:
The same that I am now,
I will continue ever.
No others high degree,
Or beautious looks shall change me:
My love shall constant be,
And no estate estrange me.
THose that have set the best at nought,
And no man could enjoy,
At last by some base gull are caught,
And gotten with a toy:
Yea, they that spend an ages light
Their favours to obtain:
For one unwilling oversight
May lose them all again.
Oh if the noblest of her time,
And best belov'd of me,
Could for so poor, so sleight a crime,
So void of pitty be.
Sure had it been some common one,
Whose patience I had try'd;
No wonder I had been undone,
Or unforgiven dyed.

div.head: ODE 2.
div.l: MAny a dainty seeming Dame
Is in Native beauty lame.
Their tyres,
Their wyres
Grace some women, but in truth
They have quite out-liv'd their youth:
One a Ruffe doth best become,
Handkerchiefs much alter some:
And their favours oft we see
Are changed as their dressings be.
Give me her is still the same
As constant as her christen name.

lg.l: I Have a love that's fair,
Rich, wise, and nobly born;
Shee's true perfections heir,
Holds nought but vice in scorn.
And yet I do not fear
(Though she my meannesse knowes)
The willow branch to wear,
No, nor the yellow hose.
Some say that love repents
Where Fortunes disagree:
I know the highest contents
From low beginnings be.
FIe, fie, forbear,
No common care
Could ever my affection chain.
Your painted baits
And poor deceits
Are all bestowed on me in vain.
My Spirit loaths
Whe • e gaudy cloaths,
And faigned oaths may love obtain.
I love her so
Whose looks swear no
That all your labours will be vain.
I can go rest,
On her sweet breast,
That is the pride of Cynthias train.
Then hold your tongues.
Your Mermaids songs
Are all bestowed on me in vain:
No, no, though clowns
Are scar'd with frowns;
I know the best can but disdain;
And those ile prove,
So shall your love
Be all bestow'd on me in vain.

div.head: ODE 3.
div.l: FAirest Caelia I did woo
And I courted Delia too.
Britomart for her love I chose,
Panthea for her Damask Rose
In her cheek, I held her dear,
And a hundred else well-near:
And in love with altogether,
Feared the enjoying either.
'Cause to be of one possest,
Bar'd the hope of all the rest.

lg.l: NOte of me was never took
For my woman-like perfections;
But so like a man I look,
It hath gain'd me best affections.
Though some lord it over me,
They in vain thereof have brav'd;
For their lusts my servants be,
Whereunto their minds are slav'd.
VVHy do foolish men so vainly
Seek contentment in their store,
Since they may perceive so plainly
I am rich in being poor.
Why are idle braines devising
How high titles may be gain'd,
Since I those poor toyes despising
Things farre higher have attain'd.
If all men could tast that sweetnesse
I do in my meannesse know:
Kings would be to seek, where greatnesse
And their honours to bestow.
Rich, or born of high degree,
Fooles aswell as you may be:
But that peace in which I live
No descent or wealth can give.

div.head: ODE 3.
div.l: NEar a pleasant Fountain side,
I a matchlesse beauty spide;
So she lay as if she slept,
But much grief her waking kept.
And she had no softer pillow
Then the hard root of a willow.
So much grief me thought she shew'd,
That my sorrowes it renew'd.
But when nearer her I went,
It increast my discontent;
For a gentle Nymph she prov'd,
Who me long (unknown) had lov'd.

lg.l: WHy (my dearest) are these frowns,
And these pitchy mists of sorrow?
Anger never none renowns:
Sure you doe these looks but borrow.
Hath my zeal occasion'd this,
Or my faith or constancy;
Oh shall ought eclipse our blisse,
One smile will cure this malady.
So those chearfull looks revive
Me, and every other creature;
Ever look so, and thou'lt give
A life that shall discredit nature.

div.head: EXAMPLES REFERRING TO EPISTOLARY EXORDIVMS For the beginnings of Letters of all sorts.
div.l: VVOrds vanish soon and vapour into ayre,
While Letters on record stand fresh and faire.
As keyes doe open chests,
So Letters open brests.

div.head: Example first.
div.p: When you see Mr. G. L. I pray tell him, that I did not think E. Waters had such a Lethaean quality in them as to cause such an Amnestia in him of his friends here upon the Thames, &c.

div.head: Example 2. To the Honorable Lady, the Lady D. C.
div.p: Whereas you were lately pleased to aske leave, you may now take Authority to command me, and did I know any of the faculties of my mind, or limbs of my body, that were not willing to serve you, I would utterly renounce them, &c.

div.head: Example the third. On the like occasion.
div.p: There is not any thing wherein I take more pleasure then in the accomplishment of your commands; nor had ever any Queen more power over her vassalls then you have o're my Intellectualls, I find by my Inclinations, that it is as naturall for me to doe your — as for fire to fly upwards, &c.

div.head: Example the fourth.
div.p: I much value the frequent respects you have shewed me, and am very covetous of the improvement of our acquaintance; for I doe not remember at home or abroad, to have seen in the person of any, a Gentleman and a Merchant so equally met, &c.

div.head: Example 5.
div.p: I confesse you have made a perfect conquest of me by your favours, and I yield my selfe your captive; a day may come that may enable me to pay my Ransome, in the interim, let a most thankfull acknowledgment be my bail and mainprise, &c.

div.head: Example 6.
div.l: FIrst shall Heavens lamp forget to shine,
The Starres shall from the skie decline;
The Orient with the West shake hand,
And the Worlds Center cease to stand:
Wolves live with Lambs, and Dolphins flye,
Lawyers, and Empericks gold deny.
Thames shall with Nyle exchange her bed;
My Mistresse locks with mine turn red:
Heaven lie below, and Hell above,
Ere I to you unconstant prove, &c.

div.head: Example 7.
div.p: I value at a high rate the fair respects you shew by the late ingenious expressions of your Letter; but the merit you ascribe unto me in the superlative, might have very well serv'd in the positive, &c.

div.head: Example 8.
div.p:
Though I am content to believe that you are firme in the fundamentalls of friendship, yet I find, under
favour, that you have lately fallen short of performing those exterior offices, as if the ceremoniall Law were quite abrogated with you in all things; friendship allowes of merits, and works of supererogation sometimes make her capable of eternity: on my part, the antient friendship is still pure, and incorrupted, and though I have not the opportunity you have, yet I shall never erre in the essentialls, &c.

div.head: Example 9.
div.p: If you continue to wrap up our young acquaintance in such warme choyce swadlings, it will quickly grow up to maturity, and for my part, I shall not be wanting to contribute that reciprocall nourishment which is due unto me.

div.head: Example 10.
div.p: In my last I writ to you that C. D. was dead, (I meant in a morall sense) he is now alive againe, for he hath abjured that Club which was wont to knock him in the head so often and drowne him commonly once aday. I discover divers Symptoms of Regeneration in him, for he railes bitterly against Bacchus, and sweares there is a Devill in every Berry of the Grape, therefore he resolves hereafter, though hee may dabble a little sometimes, he will never bee drowned againe, &c.

div.head: Example 11.
div.p:
The wishes you writ R. S. lately made, were almost as extravagant in civill matters, as the afore mentined were in naturall, for if he were partaker of them, they would draw more Inconveniences upon him then benefit, being nothing sortable to his Disposition or breeding, and for other reasons besides,
which I will reserve till I next face you, &c.

lg.l: COuld I but catch those heavenly raies
Which Phoebus at high noon displaies:
I'de set them on a Loom, and frame
A Scarse for Lydia of the same.
Could I that wondrous black come near,
Which Cynthia, when eclips'd, doth wear;
Of a new fashion I would trace
A Mask thereof for Lydias face.
Could I but reach that green and blew
Which Iris decks in various hue
From her moist brow, Id'e drag them down
To make my Lydia a summer gown.
Could I those whitely starres go nigh
Which make the milkie way i'th skie:
Ide poach, them and at Moon shine dresse
Make my Lydia a rare messe.

list.item: Yours ever to Love and serve you.
Yours most affectionately to serve you.
Yours most ready to be commanded.
Your most humble and ready servitor.
Your respectfull friend to serve you.
Your very respectfull friend to dispose of.
Your Lordships most humble and enchained servitor.
Yours in the perfect degree of friendship.

div.head: FOR LETTERS TO KNIGHTS OR GENTLEMEN.

list.item: Your most devoted and ready servitor.
Yours in no vulgar way of friendship.
Yours most ready to be commanded.
Your Lordships most true and humble servitor.
Your thrice bumble and ready servitor.
Yours in the best degree of friendship.

div.head: 1. A Girdle presented.
div.l: THis will be Venus Ceston when tis grac'd
And circumvolves thy soft and tender wast:
'Tis Naple silk, and of the Tyrian die
The first a type of thy rare mollitie.
The next doth intimate the sanguine lustre
Dwells on thy cheeks (where all the Graces cluster)
Wear it (dear heart) oh that mine armes might be
The Girdle that surrounds thy wast and thee.

div.head: 2. A Necklace of pearle presented.
div.l: The Persian Dames that proudly vie
Which shall gain th'precedency.
(For such corruption there doth sway
Shees most affected goes most gay)
Merit not halfe so much as thee
That gorgeous pomp and braverie.
They native lustre lack, and wear
It not for cloaths, would foul appear.
But nature did thee so contrive,
Thou to thy ornaments dost give
Their splendors, though these cannot deck,
Let them be grace'd by thy neck:
Where all lovers as in dutie,
Should hang Tropheys up to beauty.
'Tis proportion'd to a height,
That is even with delight.
Oh that I might sport my fill,
On that white illustrious hill.

div.head: 3. A Watch presented.
div.l: When this informes thee how the soft-foot houres
Tread on each others heeles, think how my powers,
How all my faculties doe trace each other,
Scourg'd on by Cyprian Cupid, and his Mother.
Think thy Idea doth incessantly
Present it selfe to my interior eye.
This must be kept in order, or it will
Quickly grow hoarse, or if you want the skill
To wind it wisely, soon 'tis crazd, just so
Must love be cherisht, or 'twill quickly grow
Peregrine from its pristine essence (dear)
When this poor present you shall please to wear,
Then cogitate how watchfull I will be
Ever to serve, to love, and honour thee.

div.head: 4. Sweet powder (or any other Aromatick conceit) presented.
div.l: I know no loathsome Fucus ever settles
Mixt with the (charming) Jewish fasting spettles
Vpon your splendent aspect, fair being born,
I know you doe all borrowed beauty scorn;
For he that kisses you need never fear
To find some foul unwholsome varnish there;
For he from thence may be assured hee'l sip
Nought, save the healthfull Nectar of your lip;
And at that very time, at once he closes
With melting Rubies, and odoriferous Roses.
Then think not (natures miracle) I send
This present unto any other end,
But Hieroglyphically to make known
All sweets are pestilentiall save your own.

div.head: 5. Minerva's picture presented.
div.l: I know your heart cannot delight
In any state-Hermaphrodite,
Or such froathie gallants, as
For the times Hero's passe.
Such as (still in Love) do all
Fair, and sweet, and Lady call;
And where ere they hap to stray
Either prate the rest away,
Or of all discourse to seek
Shufle in at Cent or Gleek.
None of these (I know my dear)
But as Gorgons would appear
To you, and therefore I made choice
Of her effigies, who in voice
And Gesture you outstrip, as farre
As Cynthia doth the smallest starre.
But oh, let not your wisdome prove
That like her you cannot love.

div.head: 5. A pair of gloves presented.
div.l: Let the four'st critick cast his censuring eye
And see if any polisht Ivory,
Or yet the pure and finest fleeced flocks,
Or yet the whitest of our Albion Rocks;
May for comparisons approved stand
For to expresse your faire and snowy hand:
For through the azure veins disposed true,
The crimson yields a splendant Saphire hue,
Which addes the greater grace and more delight
By intermingling with the genuine white.
Nothing more smooth, more moist, more soft & tender
Then are your rare shap'd palms, your fingers slender,
Tipt with the purest mollified pearle.
Had that Athenian (transformed) girle,
Whose more then common cunning made her dare
With Joves magnanimous daughter to compare,
But worne those hands, maugre her utmost spight,
She certainly had sham'd the Goddesse quite.
(Sweet) daign to draw these on those fair white hāds,
And when you wear them, think my being stands
Solely at your appointment, would that Love
by his great power would change me to a glove:
Your fair hand then should evermore be kist,
And I would ever dwell about your wrist.

div.head: 6. A Diamond presented.
div.l: Your selfe's a Gem that doth appear
Like the Diamond every where,
Sparkling raies of beautie forth,
All of such unblemisht worth;
That were't possible mans eye
Might your inmost thoughts espy,
And behold the dimmest part
Of the lustre of your heart;
They would find that center passe
What the superficies was;
And that every angle there
Like a Diamonds inside were.
I cannot (sure) my meaning smother,
Sending one Diamond to another.

div.head: 7. A Ring presented.
div.l: Though I prize your honour more
Then the farre fetcht pretious store,
Of the rich Molucchi, or
All the wealth was traffickt for
Since our Vessells passage knew
Unto Mexico, Peru.
Or those spacious Kingdomes which
Make the proud lberians rich:
Yet I could wish some Fate would bring,
And cage my body in this Ring.
Tradition tells us, that of yore
The Magi in those Rings they wore
Had their familiars, Oh that I
Were an imprison'd Incubi.
Your virgin Fort I would not raze,
Only on your beauty gaze.

lg.l: GO wantons now and flout at this
My coldnesse if you list.
Vain fooles, you never knew the blisse
That doth in love consist.
You sigh, and weep, and labour to enjoy
A shade, a dream, a toy.
You never took so rich content
In all your wanton play,
As this to me hath pleasure lent
That chast she went away:
But Ile no more such brunts endure.
For had Diana pure
Thus tempted been to sinne:
The Queen of Night
With her chast light
Had scarce a Maiden been.

list.item: Yours in all the bonds of affectionate service.
Yours not to be dis obliged.
Yours as you shall please to appoint.

list.head: OR THVS.
list.item: The ardent adorer of your excellent perfections.
The admirer of your worthy vertues.
To the brave and noble Lady.
To the mirrour of all perfection.
To the Mistresse of all worth.
To the truly noble, and incomparably fair.

list.head: OR THVS.
list.item: For the beautious, and most accomplished.
For the glory of her sex.
For the curteous and most debonair.
For the Mistresse of all worth.

div.head: A Gentleman having the proffer of two handsome Sisters, in the presence of his Father, thus merrily courts them.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: LAdy, what think you of a handsome Man now?

sp.speaker: 1. Lady.
sp.p: A wholsome too Sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Thats as you make your bargaine, a handsome, wholsome man then, and a kind man, to cheere your heart up, to rejoyce you Lady.

sp.speaker: 1. Lady.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I love rejoycing.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: To lye close to you? close as a Cockle? keepe the cold night from you?

sp.speaker: 1. Lady.
sp.p: That will be look't for too, our bodies aske it.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: And get two boyes at every birth?

sp.speaker: 1. Lady.
sp.p: Thats nothing, I have known a Cobler doe it, a poore thin Cobler out of mouldy Cheese perform it, Cabbage and course black bread, methinks a Gentleman should take foule scorne to have an Awle out-do him; two at a birth? every House-Dove has it: That man that feeds well, promises as well too, I should expect indeed something of worth from you, you talke of two?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: She would have me get two dozen, like buttons at a Birth.

sp.speaker: 1. Lady.
sp.p:
You love to brag sir, If you proclaim these offers
at your Marriage, ye are a pritty timberd man, take heede, they may be taken hold of, and expected, yes if not hop'd for at a higher rate too.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I will take heede and thank you for your counsell; Father what think you?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Tis a merry Gentlewoman, and no doubt will make a good wife.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Not for me; I marry her and happily get nothing, in what a state am I in then, Father? I shall suffer for any thing I heare to the contrary More Majorum, I were as sure to be a Cuckold, Father, a Gentleman of Antler; As I am sure to faile her expectation, I had rather get the P— then her Babyes.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Come yare to blame, if this do not affect ye, pray try the other, shee's of a more demure way.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: You shall have your will Sir, I will try the other, but twill be to small use. I hope fair Lady (for me thinks in your eyes I see more mercy) you will enjoyn your lover a lesse pennance; and though Ile promise much, as men are liberall, and vow an ample sacrifice or service, yet your discretion, and your tendernesse and thriftinesse in Love, good housewives carefulnesse to keep the stock entire—

sp.speaker: 2. Lady.
sp.p: Good sir speak louder, that these may witnesse to the talk of nothing, I should be sorry alone to bear the burden of so much indiscretion.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Hark ye, hark ye, ods bobs, you are angry Lady.

sp.speaker: 2. Lady.
sp.p: Angry? no sir I never own'd an anger to lose poorly.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: But you can love for all this, and delight too for all your set austeritie to hear of a good husband Lady

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: You say true Sir, for by my troth I have heard of none these tenne years, they are so rare; and there are so many sir, so many longing women on their knees too; that pray the dropping down of these good Husbands, the dropping down from heaven, for they are not bred here.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: But can ye love a Man Lady?

sp.speaker: 2. Lady
sp.p: Yes, if the man be lovely, that is, be modest, honest; I would have him valiant, his anger slow but certain for his honour, travaild he should be, but through himselfe exactly, for tis fairer to know manners well, then countries: he must be no vain talker, nor no lover to hear himselfe talk; they are brags of a wonderer, if one finds no retreat for fair behaviour. Would ye learn more?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: 2. Lady.
sp.p: Learn to hold your peace then; fond Girles are got with tongues, women with tempers.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Women with I know what, but let that vanish: go thy way good wife, be sure thy husband must have a strong Philosophers stone, he will nere please thee else. Here's a starcht piece of austeritie, dee hear Father, do you hear this morall lecture?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Yes, and like it.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Why theres your judgment now, there's an old bolt shot, this thing must have the strongest observation; do you mark me Father? when she is once married, the strangest custome too of admiration on all she does and speaks, 'twill be past sufferance; I must not lie with her in common language, nor cry have at thee Kate, I shall be hist then, nor eat my meat without the sauce of sentence, your powdred beef and problems, a rare diet, my first sonne Monsieur Aristotle, I know it, great Master of the Metaphysicks, or so. The second Solon and the best Lawsetter, and I must look Egyptian Godfathers, which will be no small trouble. My eldest daughter Sapho, or such a kind of fidling Poetesse, and brought up Invita Minerva at her needle: my dogs must look their names too. Think you Ile be married to a sullen set of sentences, to one that weighs her words, and her behaviours in the goldweights of discretion? He be hang'd first.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Prithee reclaim thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Pray ye give me time then; if they can set me any thing to play at, that seemes fit for a gamester. Have at the fairest, till I see more, and try more.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Take your own time then, ile bar you no fair liberty.

div.head: A rich Widow being over-reacht by a Gentleman somewhat decayed, after some falling out is thus accosted by him.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: THis need not have been Widdow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You say right Sir, no, nor your treachery, your close conspiracy against me for my wealth, need not have been.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I had you fairly, I scorn treachery to your woman that I never meant to marry; much more to you whom I reserv'd for wife.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How! wife?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I, wife, wife, Widdow, be not asham'd on't, it's the best calling ever women came to, and all your grace indeed, brag as you list.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I grant you Sir, but not to be your wife.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Not mine? I thinke 'tis the best bargain that ere thou mad'st i'thy life, or ever shall agen, when my heads laid; but that's not yet this threescore years, let's talk of neerer matters.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Y'are as near Sir, as ever y'are like to be, if Law can right me.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Now before conscience y'are a wilfull housewife.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I, and I fear you spend my goods lavishly.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Your goods?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I shall misse much I doubt, when I come to look over the Inventory.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ile give you my word you shall Sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Look to't Widow, a night may come will call you to accompt for't.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O if ye had me now Sir in this heat, I do but think how youl'd be reveng'd on mee.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I may I perish else, if I would not get three children a birth, an I could o'thee.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well Sir, take your course, yet you may misse your ayme.

div.head: A Lady being encountered by three Suitors, two old, but rich, the third young and poor, thus speaks for her selfe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: GEntlemen, had fortune thrown me upon any of you, yet were your labours lost, all your aimes and hopes; for to an honest Gentleman my brother I've made a deed of gift of all.

sp.speaker: 1. Old Suit.
sp.p: Ha' you serv'd me so Lady?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I must not looke for pleasures that give more griefe if they prove false or faile us, then sure they gave joy, I must take one that loves me for my selfe, and sir, I'm sure you looke not after wealth, but vertue, manners, and conditions.

sp.speaker: 1. Old suit.
sp.p: Yes by my troth, I must have Lands and Lordships too Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: 1. Old suit.
sp.p: Your manners, Vertue and Conditions Lady are pritty things within doores, I like well on'em, but I must have something without lying or being in the tenure and Occupation of Mr. Such a one, ha? those are of Mr. Things indeed.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why sir, you swore to me it was for Love.

sp.speaker: 1. Old suit.
sp.p: True, but there's two words to a bargain ever, all the world over, and if love be one, I'me sure money's the other, 'tis no bargain else. Pardon me, I must dine aswell as sup Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Cra mercy, I mistook you all this while Sir, it was this antient Gentleman indeed whom I crave pardon on.

sp.speaker: 2 Old suit.
sp.p: What of me Lady?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Alas I have wrong'd you Sir, 'twas you that swore you lov'd me for my selfe.

sp.speaker: 2. Old suit.
sp.p:
By my faith but I did not, come, father not your lies on me, I love you for your selfe? spit at me
Gentlemen if ere I'de such a thought. Fetch me in? no, your reach's too short.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why you have enough you say? and whom now shall a woman trust, ile swear 'twas one of you made me believe so; Masse I think it was you sir, now I remember me.

sp.speaker: Young suit.
sp.p: I swore too much, to be beleeved so little.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Was it you then? beshrew my heart for wronging you.

sp.speaker: Young suit.
sp.p: Welcome blessing, are you mine faithfully now?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: As Love can make one, else may all faith forsake me.

div.head: A zealous brother being moved by the Spirit, in a dark night perceives a Gentlewoman walking the streets, and makes towards her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: THat Lady should be right by her swimming gate, I am provok't, and must have ease. Sister, Sister, hist, hist, why Sister?

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Would you ought with me Sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Lady, tis dark.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Tis very true sir, can you make it lighter?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
My directions (fair Lady) will be no stumbling
block to you, and if my heartily proffered service appear not troublesome, I shall performe the duty of a servant, and wait upon you home.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Sir I thank you, but yet methinks your habit and your language are not well matcht.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: However matcht, they shall agree to do you service.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Sir, to give you answer. I am this night to encounter with a friend of mine about some businesse that much concernes my livelyhood.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Lady, shall I request you make me then so happy as let me know where I may wait on you to morrow.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: So it be in the evening, where you please.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Pray name the place most convenient for you, and Ile not fail to attend you.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: What think you of the naked Boy in flesh lane.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The hower now, and Ile not fail you Lady.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: 'Tween foure and five in the evening.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Till when your faithfull servant Lady, all happinesse attend you.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Goodnight to you curteous Sir.

div.head: Jasperino, a merry fellow, at first fight thus boards the Joviall Diaphanta.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.p: I Am a mad wag Wench.

sp.speaker: Diaph.
sp.p: So me thinks, but for your comfort I can tell you, we have a Doctor in the Citty that undertakes the cure of such.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.p: Tush, I know what Physick is best for the state of my own body.

sp.speaker: Diaph.
sp.p: 'Tis scarce a well govern'd state then I believe.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.p: I could shew thee such a thing now with an ingredient that we two would compound together, and if it did not time the maddest blood i'th town for two howers after, Ile nere professe Physick agen.

sp.speaker: Diaph.
sp.p: A little poppy Sir, were good to cause you sleep.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.p: Poppy, Ile give thee a pop 'ith lip for that first, and begin there: Poppy is one simple indeed, but Ile discover no more now, another time Ile shew thee all.

div.head: A Dialogue betwixt an old jealous Doctor, and his man.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: JAcomo, I must trust thee with a secret, but thou must keep it.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I was ever close to a secret sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: The diligence that I have found in thee, the care and industry already past, assures me of thy good continuance. Iacomo I have a Wife.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Fie sir, tis too late to keep your secret, shees known to be marryed all the Town and country over.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Thou goest too farre my Iacomo, that knowledge I confesse no man can be barr'd it, but there's a knowledge which is neerer, deeper, and sweeter Iacomo.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Well Sir, let us handle that between you and I.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Tis that I go about man; Iacomo, my wife is young.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: So much the worse to be kept secret Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why now thou meetest the substance of the point, I am old Iacomo.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: No Sir, tis I am old Iacomo.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Yet why may not this concord and sympathize, old Trees and young Plants often grow together, and agree well enough.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: But Sir the old Trees raise themselves higher and broader then the young Plants.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Shrewd application, thers the fear man, I would wear my Ring on my own finger, whilst it is borrowed it is none of mine, but his that useth it.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: You must keep it on still then, if it but lye by, one or other will be thrusting into't.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Thou conceivest me Iacomo, here thy watchfull eyes must have employment, for I cannot be alwaies at home.

div.head: A Gentleman to obtain the love of his Lady, faignes himselfe Mad, and thus courts her in his keepers absence.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: TIs a blest opportunity sweet Lady; nay cast no amazing eye upon this change.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Ha! what sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: This shape of folly shrouds your dearest Love, the truest servant to your powerfull beauty, whose Magick had this force thus to transform him.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: You are a fine fool indeed.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: O 'tis not strange, Love has an intellect that runnes through all the sciences, and like a cunning Poet catches a quantity of every knowledg, and brings all home into one Mystery.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Y'are a parious Fool.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: No danger in me, I bring nought but Love, and his soft wounding shafts to strike you with, try but one Arrow, if it hurt you, ile send you twenty back in recompence.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: A forward fool too.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: This was loves teaching, a thousand waies she fashion'd out my way, and this I found the safest and neerest to tread the Galaxia to my starre.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Profound withall, certain you dreampt of this, Love never taught it waking.

div.head: A Gentleman being intreated by his friend to Court his Mistresse for him, thus Indeavours to acquit himselfe of his Charge.

sp.speaker: Cratander.
sp.p: SAve you faire Lady, I wish you health and your owne wishes upon you.

sp.speaker: Evanthe.
sp.p: If that be all, I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Cratand.
sp.p: But Lady, I have businesse beyond a bare salute, and tis of my friend Theocles his service to you Lady.

sp.speaker: Evanthe.
sp.p: Well, proceed.

sp.speaker: Cratan.
sp.p: Hees one if faith can beare the stamp of merit, deserves your Love, he spends the dayes in teares, and by his sighes, with which he counts his houres he makes voyd minutes; Thus he pines away, and in a sullen griefe hath lost himselfe onely for love of you.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.p:
Alas I pitty the poore Gentleman, bid him rise early, use good company, and know no other moysture
but of wine, twill cure his Melancholy.

sp.speaker: Crat.
sp.p: If you return but this sleight answer, know, you then will draw a new disease upon him, and your cure will only grow to a deeper wound, whilst he shall dye with Physick.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.p: Indeed you urge his suit so full, as if he had bequeathd his soul into your bosome, but I pray you discourse it coolly, should I give my selfe to every one that this way would deserve me, I should be marryed to a troop of men, and grow a lawfull strumpet; for my face is not of that poor clay, as to be courted with one flame only; there are more desires chain'd to my eyes then his.

sp.speaker: Crat.
sp.p: There may be so, and that face doth deserve it; but in all that heap of suitors, there are few can boast of a flame so vigorous as that of Theocles, all do not testifie their rude affections with that best complement of gaudy presents, nor woe i'th costly language of rich gifts; this is the stile of Theocles firme Love printed in gold.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.p: I grant indeed he sent full choice of presents, and the finest toyes as I could wish; but I return'd him thanks, and paid him still in a Civillity, it he expect more, I recall that too: alas I have no price set on me, nor am sold at the cheap rate of Jewells; Ile not passe my selfe away by bargain.

sp.speaker: Crat.
sp.p:
Lady, he scornes to chaffer for affection, he desires that you should recompence his faith with yours and not his gifts: Nor is he arm'd only with gifts, he dare even challenge dangers, and provoke
death, if he might thus avoid the Fate which he more fears of your displeasure, he dares fight for you, and maintain your beauty, whilst he shall lose his own, and paint your face fresh with his blood.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.p: I here's a way indeed, a fine device thus to defend my beauty that he might ruine it; that Ladies name whose worth must be decided by the sword, suffers though in a conquest; 'tis a stain to honour, while it wants another force then its own innocence to guard it.

sp.speaker: Crat.
sp.p: Lady y'are too severe thus to despise all waies that render suitors lovely; if you doubt his constancy, invent your selfe a tryall, impose some harder task, whose cruell weight might shake a faith which was as firm as a Rock.

div.head: One who had marryed his owne whore by a mistake thus takes on.

sp.speaker: Stremon.
sp.p: DEath, whom have I married here? mine own Whore.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.p: With whom else should ye marry, speak your conscience, will ye transgresse the Law of armes, that ev •• rewards the Souldier with his owne sins?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.p: Devills rather.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.p: Ye had my Maidenhead, my Youth, my Sweetnesse, is it not justice then?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.p: Well I see it must be, but by this hand Ile hang a Lock upon thee.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.p: You shall not need, my honesty shall do it.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.p: If there be Warres in all the world—

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.p: Ile with you, for ye know I have been a souldier. Come, curse on, but tis so no purpose.

div.head: A Gentleman having assumed the quality of a Servant, gets admittance into a mans house whose wife he loved.

sp.speaker: Richardo.
sp.p: I Have told you now all my story, how desperately I loved you, and what means I used to purchase this opportunity.

sp.speaker: Violante.
sp.p: I doe believe. Lets walk on, time is pretious, not to be spent in words, here's no more wooing, the open ayre's an enemy to Lovers, do as I tell ye.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Ile do any thing I am so over-joy'd, ile fly to serve ye

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Take your joy moderately, as it is ministred, and as the cause invites, that mans a fool that at the sight o'th bond dances and leaps, then is the true joy when the mony comes.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: You cannot now deny me.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Nay you know not, women have crotchets and strange fitts.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: You shall not.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p:
Hold ye to that and swear it confidently, then I
shall make a scruple to deny ye: pray ye lets step in and see a friend of mine; the weathers sharp, weel stay but halfe an hower, we may be mist else; a private fine house 'tis sir, and we may find many good welcomes.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Do Lady, do happy Lady.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: All your mind's of doing, you must be modester.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I will do any thing so you do not deny me.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Come then, lets in, and be you ruld by me.

div.head: A blunt Captain that cared not for women, being drunk, chang'd his mind, and thus saluts two Gentlewomen whom he formerly quarrell'd with.

sp.speaker: Iaques.
sp.p: LAdies I am somewhat bold, but thats all one.

sp.speaker: Clora.
sp.p: A short and pithy saying of a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Francisca.
sp.p: As I live thou art a strange mad wench.

sp.speaker: Clora.
sp.p: To make a parson.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Ladies I mean to kiss ye.

sp.speaker: Clora.
sp.p: How he wipes his mouth like a young preacher, we shall have it.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: In order as you lie before me, first Ile begin with you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: With me sir?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Yes if you will promise to kiss in ease.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I care not if I venture.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I will kiss according to my own invention, as I shall see cause: sweetly I would wish you, I love ye.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Doe you indeed sir?

sp.speaker: Iaq
sp.p: Yes indeed do I, I would I could tell you how.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I would you would Sir.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I would to God I could, but 'tis sufficient I love you with my heart.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Alas poor heart.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: And I am sorry; but weel talk of that hereafter if it please God.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Even when you please Sir.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Hees dismall drunk, would he were muzled.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: You I take it are the next.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Now dare, not I come near him, he will bite me.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: When witt, when?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Good Coptain.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Nay an you play bopeep, ile have no mercy, but catch as catch may.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Good Captain do not hurt me, I am sorry that ere I angred ye.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Ile tew you for't by this hand, witt, unlesse you kiss discreetly.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: No more sir.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Yes a little more sweet witt, one tast more o'your of ••• e, go thy waies with thy small kettle-drums, upon my conscience thou art the best that ere man laid his leg ore.

div.head: A Gentlewoman having implyed her Man to find out one upon whom she had cast a favourable eye, thus examines him.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: COme hither Sirrah, what was he, we sent you after, the Gentleman i'th black.

sp.speaker: Lollio.
sp.p: I'th torne black?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Yes the same sir.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: What would your Worship with him?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Why my worship would know his name, and what he is.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: He is nothing, he is a man, and yet he is no Man.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You must needs play the Fool.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: Tis my profession.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: How is he a man and no man?

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: He's a begger, only the signe of a man, the bush pul'd down, which showes the house stands empty.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Whats his calling?

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: They call him begger.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Whats his Kindred?

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: Beggers.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: His worth?

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: A learned begger a poore Scholler.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: How doth he live?

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: Like wormes, he eates old bookes.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Is Valentine his Brother?

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: His begging brother.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: What may his name be?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Leave your fooling.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: You had as good say leave your living.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Once more tell me directly whats his name?

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: I'le bee hang'd first, unlesse I heard him Christened, but I can tell what foolish people call him.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Say, what ist?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Where lyes this learning sir?

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: In Pauls Church yard forsooth.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I meane that Gentleman Foole.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: O that Foole, he lyes in loose sheetes every where, that's no where.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: You have glean'd since you came to London, in the Country Lollio you were an arrant foole, a dull cold Coxcome, here every Taverne teaches you, the pint pot has so belabour'd you with witt, and your brave acquaintance that gives you Ale, so fortifies your Mazard, that now ther's no talking to you, you are so much improv'd, so fine a discourser.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: I hope so, I have not waited at the taile of wit so long, as that I should be an Asse now.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But I pray sir have a care lest you down into the Country againe.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: Ile rather dye then goe.

div.head: A Gentlewoman whose Maid had betraid some of her Loves secrets, thus chides her.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: HOw Iacinta, did you indeed betray me?

sp.speaker: Iacinta.
sp.p: By my troth Mistresse I did it for the best.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: It may be so Iacinta, but yet you have a tongue, a dish of meate in your mouth, which if were minc'd would doe a great deale better.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I protest Mistress.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: It will be your own one time or another, you are so full of providence.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: But heare me.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I am in Love sweet Iacinta, and you are so skilfull, that I must needs undoe my selfe.

sp.speaker: Iac.
