sp.p: Pray you be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Yes and contented too, before I leave you, ther's a Roger, which some call Butcher, I speake of certainties, I doe not fish Iacinta, doe not stare, I have a tongue can talke too, and a green chamber with a back doore open to a long gallery, there was a night, doe you perceive me yet, oh doe you blush, a Friday night I saw your Saint Iacinta, for to'ther box of Marmalate all's thine sweet Roger, this I heard and kept too.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Even as you are a woman Mistress.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: This I allow as good and physicall sometimes, these meetings are for the cheering of the heart, but Iacinta, to have your own turne servd, and your friend to be a dog-bolt.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I confesse it Mistress.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Well then, be sure you strive to regain my sister back to her usuall Temper, else you lose my Love.

div.head: A merry cross wooing between a Gentleman, and his Lady.

sp.speaker: Baptista.
sp.p: GOod morrow Kate, for that I hears your name.

sp.speaker: Katherine.
sp.p: Well have you heard, but something hard of hearing, they call me Katherine that do talk of me.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.p: You lie in faith, for you are called plain Kate, and bony Kate, and sometimes Kate the curst: but Kate take this of me for thy consolation, hearing thy mildnesse praised in every town, thy vertues spoke of, and thy beauty sounded, yet not so loud, as unto thee belongs. My selfe am moved to woo thee for my Wife.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Mov'd in good time, let him that moved you hither, remove you hence; I knew you at the first you were a Movable.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Why, whats a movable?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: A joyn'd stoole.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Thou hast hit it, come sit on me.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Asses are made to bear, and so are you.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Women are made to bear, and so are you.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: No such Jades Sir as you, if me you mean.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Alas good Kate, I will not burden thee, for knowing thee to be but young and light.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Too light for such a swain as you to catch, and yet as heavie as my weight should be.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Should be, should: Buzz.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Well tane, and like a Buzzard.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: O slow-wing'd Turtle, shall a Buzzard take thee.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: I for a Turtle, as he takes a Buzzard.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Come, come, you wasp, in faith you are too angry.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: If I be waspish, best beware my sting.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: My remedie is then to pluck it out.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I if the foal could find it where it lies.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Who knowes not where a Wasp wears his sting? in his tail.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: In his tongue.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Whose tongue?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Yours if you talk of tales, and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: What with my tongue in your tail? nay come again good Kate, I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: That Ile try with a box o'th ear.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: I swear I'le cuffe you if you strike again.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: So you may lose your armes, if you strike me, you are no Gentleman, and if no Gentleman, why then no armes.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: A Herald Kate, O put me in thy books.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: What is your Crest? a Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: A comblesse Cock, so Kate will be my Hen.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: No Hen of yours, you look so like a Craven.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Nay come Kate, come, you must not look so sowre.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: It is my fashion when I see a Crab.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Why heres no Crab, and therefore look not sowre.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: There is, there is.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Then prethee shew it me.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Had I a glass I would.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: what you mean my face?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: well aim'd of such a young one.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Now by St. Grorge I am too young for you.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Yet you are withered.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Tis with cares.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I care not.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Nay hear me Kate, good-faith you scape not so.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: I chafe you if I tarry, let me go.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: No not a whit, I find you passing gentle, 'twas told me you were rough, and coy, and sullen, and now I find report a very Lyar, for thou art pleasant, and passing courteous, thou canst not frown nor bite the lip as other women doe.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: where did you study all this goodly speech.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: It is ex-tempore, from my Mother-witt.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: A witty Mother, witlesse else her sonne.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Am I not wise?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Yes, keep you warme.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Marry so I mean sweet Katherin in thy Bed, and therefore since all things betwixt me and your, Father are agreed upon, know Katherin you must be my wife.

div.head: A Gentleman for his Lord, thus courts a Lady who falls in Love with him.

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.p: MOst accomplish'd Lady, my matter hath no voice but to your own ear.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: You have it Sir, give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: My dutie Madam, and most humble service

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What is your name?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Lorenzo is your servants name, fairest Lady.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: And what I pray Sir may your businesse be.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Madam, it is to tell you that my Lord and Master loves you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: how does he love me?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: With Adorations, with most fertile tears, with groans that thunder Love, with sighes of fire.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: For him, I think not on him, for his thoughts, would they were blanks rather then filled with me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughts on his behalfe.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: O by your leave I pray you, I bad you never speake of him againe, but would you undertake another suit, I had rather heare you to solicite that, then Musick from the spheares.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Lady farwell, I dare not heare you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Stay Lorenzo, for by Maid-hood honour, truth and all that's good, I Love thee.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Madam Adieu, will you nothing to my Lord by me.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Yes, come againe, for thou perhaps maist move my heart to like his Love.

div.head: A Gentleman meeting his Lady in the Streets in a good mind, is thus perswaded by her to Church, and Marryes her.

sp.speaker: Francisco.
sp.p: GOod morrow Lady.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: How now, what's that?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Nay never blesse your selfe, I am but a Man.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What doe you meane, who sent for you? cannot I goe about my private Meditations, but such companions as you must ruffle me, you had best goe with me Sir?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Twas my purpose.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What an impudence is this, you had best being so neere the Church provide a Priest, and perswade me to marry you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Twas my meaning, and such a Husband so loving and so carefull will I prove.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Tis strange you should be thus unmannerly, you had best force my man to leade your way.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes marry shall a Lady, forward honest friend.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: This a pritty Riott, this may grow to a Rap • .

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Do you like that better, I can ravish you an hundred times, and do you no hurt.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Are you in earnest sir, do you long to be hanged.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes by my troth Ladie, in these fair tresses.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Shall I call out for help?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No by no means, that were a weak trick Lady, Ile kiss and stop your mouth.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Youl answer all these?

sp.speaker: Fran
sp.p: A thousand kisses more.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: I was never abused thus, you had best give out too, that you found me willing, and say I doted on you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: That's known already, and no man living shall now carry you from me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: This is fine in faith.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: It shall be ten times finer.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Well, seeing you are so valiant, keepe your way, I will to Church.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And I will wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: And it is most likely there is a Priest, if you dare venture as you profess; I would wish you looke about you, to doe these rude tricks, for you know their recompence, and trust not to my mercy.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But I will Lady.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: For I'le so handle you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: That's it I looke for.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Follow now sir if you dare.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: If I doe not, hang me.

div.head: A Gentleman meeting a Lady veil'd thus salutes her.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I Pray let me see your face.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, you must pardon me, for women of our sort that maintaine fair memories, and keepe suspect off from their Chastities, had heed weare thicker vailes.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I am no blaster of a Ladies Beauty, nor bold intruder on her speciall Favours, I know how tender Reputation is, and with what guards it ought to bee preserved, you may to me Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You must excuse me signior, I come not here to sell my selfe.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: As I am a Gentleman, and by the honour of a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I beleeve you, and I pray you be civill, I beleeve you would see me, and when you have seene mee, I beleeve you will like me, but in a strange place to a stranger too, as if I came on purpose to betray you, indeed I will not.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I shall Love you dearely, and tis a sin to fling away affection, I have no Mistresse, no desire to honour any but you; I know not, you have struck me with your modesty so deepe, and taken from me all desires I might bestow on others, that I must needs see your face.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Indeed sir I dare not, but since I see you are so desirous to view a poore face that can merit nothing but your Repentance.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: It must needs be excellent.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come but to my house, which is neere St. Sebastines, and there you shall see what you so much desire.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Ile kisse your faire white hand and thank you Lady.

div.head: One having gained entrance into a Gentlewomans house, thus Courts her.

sp.speaker: Horatio.
sp.p: MAy I be so bold Lady, as to aske if you are a Maid?

sp.speaker: Vallia.
sp.p: You make me blush to answer sir, I ever was accounted so to this hower, and that's the reason why I live retir'd sir.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Then would I counsell you to marry presently, for every year you lose, you lose a beauty, a husband now, an honest carefull Husband were such a comfort.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I am not so strict sir, nor tyed unto a Virgins solitariness, but if an honest, and a noble one, Rich, and a Souldier, for so have I vowed he shall be, were offer'd me, I thinke I should accept him, but above all he must Love.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: He were base else, I am a Bachelor and a Souldier Lady, and such a wife as you, I could Love infinitly.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are a true Gentleman and faire I see by you, and such a man I had rather take.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Pray doe so, Ile have a Priest o'th sudden.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And as suddenly you will repent too.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Ile bee hang'd or drown'd first, by this and this and this kisse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are a flatterer, but I must say there was something when I saw you first in that most noble face that stirr'd my fancy.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Ile stirre it better er'e you sleepe sweet Lady, Ile give up all I have to your dispose before I bed ye, And then sweet wench.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You have the Art to Cozen me.

div.head: A SONG. By one whose Wife was too hard for him.
div.l: FRom Harpies Nailes, from Furies whips,
From all sharp Noses, and thin Lips;
From two Legg'd Catts, with thrice nine lives,
From Scalding Wort, from Scolding Wives.
From fulmouth'd blasts, from female blowes,
From smooth fac'd Slutts, from sharpnail'd shrowes,
From wounds t'inflict, from plagues to infect mee,
My Genius blesse, my starres protect mee.

lg.l: O Draw your Curtaines and appeare
Ere long, like sparkes that upward fly,
We can but vainely say you were,
So soone you'l vanish from the eye.
And in what starr we both shall find,
(For sure you can't divided bee)
Is not to Lovers Art assign'd,
Twill Puzzle wise Astrology.
IS any sick? is any sore
Opprest with qualmes or fainting fitts?
Or bound behind? or loose before?
Has any Lover lost his witts?
Let him draw neere,
And make his griefe appeare;
Wee'l cure them all from top to toe,
Before, behind, about, below.
Is any heart opprest with dolor?
Sullen, sad, or Melancholy?
Ore flown with blood? inflam'd with Choler?
Or surcharg'd with flegm or folly;
Let him draw neer,
And make his grief appear;
Weel ease you all what ere you feele,
Within, without, from head to heele.
Is any foule that would be faire?
Would Rav'ns appeare as white as Lambs?
Has any Courtier lost his haire?
Or finds a crinkling in his Hamms?
Let him draw neer,
And make his griefs appeare;
Wee'l cure all their wants throughout,
Above, below, within, without.
Has any Morphewes, Frickles, Flames,
Warts or Wounds, Wenns, or Scarrs?
Blisters, Botches, Biles, or Blaines,
Coughes, Consumptions, Colds, Catarrs?
Let them draw neer,
And make their griefs appeare;
Wee'l make them sound from bone to skin,
Above, below, without, within.
Collicks, Fevers, Palsies, Flux,
Cancers, Dropsies, Nauseous Fumes?
Megrums, Scurvies, Cramps, or Crieks,
Janders, Rickets, Piles or Rhumes?
Let them draw neer,
And make their griefs appeare;
Wee'l give them Ease and health restore,
Within, without, behind, before.
TIme is a featherd thing,
And whilst I praise
The sparklings of thy lookes, and call them Rayes,
Take wings;
Leaving behind him as he flyes,
An unperceived dimness in thine eyes.
His minuts whilst th'are told,
Do make us old;
And every sand of his swift Glasse,
Increasing age as it doth passe.
Insensibly sowes Winkels there,
Where flowers and Roses do appear.
Whilst we do speak, our fire
Doth into Ice expire.
Flames turn to frost,
And ere we can
Know how our Crow turnes Swan:
Or how a silver Snow
Our fading Spring is in dull Winter lost.
Since then the night hath hurl'd
Darknesse, Loves shade
Over its enemy the day, and made
The World
Just such a blind and shapelesse thing,
As twas before light did from darknesse spring:
Let us employ his treasure,
And make shade our pleasure:
Lets number out the howers by blisses,
And count the Minutes by our kisses:
Let the heavens new motions feel,
And by our imbraces wheel.
And whilst we try the way,
By which Love doth convey
Soul into soul,
And mingled so
Makes them such raptures know,
As makes them intranc'd lye
In mutuall extasie.
Let the Harmonious Sphears in Musick roule.
BEhold these hallowed Tapers, and here see
What Wells and springs of fire they be.
How their two lustres twining
Make mutuall shining,
Whilst one from the other kindled doth requite
It's borrowed, with as great a light for light,
And kindles back again.
And thus combining raies with raies,
And joyning flames like Marriage daies,
A holy Nuptiall 'twixt them do maintain.
Yet these but the dark signes and emblems be
Of those concealed fires, which none see
But Gods, and such whose eyes
Love glorifies.
Between these Breasts a sacred flame doth spring,
Which intermingling Rites, whilst we do sing,
Is to it selfe the Priest.
Whilst Heart with Heart thus interwov'd,
And Paires made one, the Lov'd with Lov'd
Themselves between themselves in Hymens twist.
NOw what is Love, I will thee tell,
It is the Fountain and the Well
Where pleasures and repentance dwell:
It is perhaps the Sanceing Bell
That Rings all into Heaven or Hell;
And this is Love, and this is Love as I here tell.
Now what is Love I will thee show,
A thing that creeps and cannot go;
A prize that passeth to and fro,
A thing for me, a thing for mo,
And he that proves shall find it so.
And this is Love, & this is love sweet friend I tro.
VVHy since we Souldiers cannot prove,
And grief it is to us therefore,
Let every man get him a Love,
To trim her well and fight no more.
That we may tast of Lovers blisse,
Be merry and wise, embrace and kisse,
That Ladies may say, some more of this,
That Ladies may say some more of this.
Since Court and Citty both grow proud,
And safety you delight to hear;
We in the Country will us shroud,
Where lives to please both eye and ear.
The Nightingale sings Jug, jug, jug,
The little Lamb leaps after his Dug,
And the pretty Milk-maids they look so smug,
And the pretty Milk-maids they look so smug.
GO happy heart, for thou shalt lie
Intomb'd in her for whom I die
Example of her cruelty.
Tell her if she chance to chide
Me for slownesse in her pride,
That it was for love I dy'd.
If a tear escape her eye,
Tis not for my memory,
But thy rights of Obsequy.
The Altar was my loving Breast,
My Heart the sacrificed Beast,
And I was my selfe the Priest.
Your Bodie was the sacred shrine,
Your cruell mind the power divine,
Pleas'd with the hearts of Men, not Kine.
BEauty cleare and faire,
Where the Ayre
Rather like a perfume dwells,
There the Violet and the Rose,
There blew veines in Blush disclose,
And come to Honour nothing else.
Where to live neere,
And planted there,
So to live and still live new,
When to gaine a favour is
More then Light, perpetuall bliss,
Make me live by serving you.
Deare againe back call
To this Light,
A stranger to himselfe and all
Both the wonders, and the story,
Shall be yours, and the glory,
I'm your servant and your Thrall.
The Fitt's upon me now,
The fitt's upon me now;
Come quickly gentle Lady,
The fitt's upon me now.
The World shall know th'are fooles,
And so shalt thou do too,
Let the Cobler meddle with his tooles,
The fitt's upon me now.
COme, come, my troubled thoughts stay & admire,
Call home your erring Fellowes, make a stand,
Follow not still the Colors of desire,
False are her wishes, Cruell her Demands.
Come then obey this Summons, come away,
For here vaine hopes must serve you for your pay.
Beauty and Love dye even as they were borne,
Time is their Foe, the weakest Sex their guard;
Ambitions ends, deaths power, and fortunes scorne,
Like timelesse fruit withers without reward.
Come then obey this summons, come away,

div.head: A MAYDENS SONG For her Dead Lover.

lg.l: COme you whose Loves are dead,
And whilst I sing,
Weepe and wring,
Every hand, and every head
Bind with Cypresse and sad Ewe,
Ribbands black and Candles blue;
For him that was of men most true.
Come with heavy mourning,
And on his grave
Let him have
Sacrifice of sighes and groaning,
Let him have faire flowers enough,
White and purple, green and yellow,
For him that was of men most true.

div.head: A SONG.
div.l: BEtter Musick neere was known,
Then a quire of Hearts in one,
Let each other that hath been,
Troubled with the Gall or Spleen,
Learne of us to keepe his brow;
Smooth and plaine as ours is now.
Sing though before the houre of dying,
He shall rise and then be crying.
Hey ho, tis nought but mirth,
That keepes the body from the earth.

div.head: THE FAYRIES SONG.
div.l: Fy on sinfull Phantacy,
Fy on Lust and Luxury;
Lust is but a bloody fire,
Kindled with unchast desire.
Fed in heart whose flames aspire,
As thoughts do blow them higher and higher.
Pinch him Fairies mutually,
Pinch him for his villanie;
Pinch him, and burne him, and burne him about,
Till candles and starlight, and moonshine be out.

lg.l: SIgh no more Ladyes, sigh no more,
Men were deceivers ever,
One foot in Sea, and one on shore;
To one thing constant never.
Then sigh not so, but let them go,
And be you blith and bonny,
Converting all your sounds of woe,
Into hey nonny nonny.
Sing no more ditties, sing no more,
Of dumps so dull and heavy;
The fraud of men was ever so,
Since Summer first was leavy.
Then sigh not so, but let them go,
And be you blith and bonny;
Converting all your sounds of woe.
Into hey nonny nonny.
DId not the heavenly Rhetorick of thine eye,
'Gainst whom the world cannot hold argument,
Perswade my heart to this false perjury?
Vowes for thee broke deserve not punishment.
A Woman I forswore, but I will prove,
Thou being a Goddesse, I forswore not thee;
My vow was earthly, thou a heavenly Love,
Thy grace being gaind, cures all disgrace in me.
Vowes are but breath, and breath a vapour is,
Then thou fair Sun, which on my earth doth shine
Exhal'st this Vapour-vow, in thee it is:
If broken then, it is no fault of mine.
If by me broke what foole is not so wise,
To lose an oath, and win a Paradise.

div.head: ANOTHER.
div.l: ON a day alacke the day,
Love whose moneth is every May,
Spied a blossome passing faire,
Playing in the wanton Ayre.
Through the velvet leaves the wind,
All unseene can passage find;
That the Lover sick to death,
Wish'd himselfe the Heavens breath.
Agree (quoth he) thy Cheeke may blow,
Ayre would I might tryumph so,
But alack my hand is sworne
Nere to pluck thee from thy throne:
A vow, alas for youth unmeet,
Youth so apt to pluck a sweet:
Doe not call it sin in mee,
That I am forsworn to thee:
Thou for whom great love would sweare,
Iuno but an Aethiop were:
And deny himselfe for Jove,
Turning Mortall for thy Love.

lg.l: VNder the green wood Tree,
Who loves to lye with mee;
And turns his merry Note
Unto the sweet-birds throat.
Come hither, come hither, come hither,
Here shall he see
No enemy,
But VVinter and rough weather.
Who doth ambition shunne,
And loves to live ith' Sun,
Seeking the food he eats,
And pleas'd with what he getts,
Come hither, come hither, come hither,
Here shall he see
No enemy,
But Winter and rough Weather.
If it doe come to passe
That any man turn Asse;
Leaving his wealth and ease,
A stubborn will to please.
Come hither, come hither, come hither,
Here shall he see
Gross fooles as hee;
And if he will come to me.
O Mistresse mine, where are you Romeing,
O stay and hear, your true love's comming,
That can sing both high and low;
Trip no further pretty sweeting,
Journeys and in Lovers meeting
Every wise-mans sonne doth know.
What is Love, 'tis not hereafter,
Present mirth hath present laughter:
What's to come, is still unsure.
In delay there lies no plenty,
Then come kisse me sweet and twenty,
Youths a stuffe will not indure.
COme away, come away death,
And in sad Cypresse let me be laid:
Fy away, fie away breath,
I am slain by a fair cruel Maid.
My shroud of white stuck all with Ewe,
O prepare it;
My heart of death no one so true
Did share it.
Not a flower, nor a flower sweet,
On my black coffin let there be strewn:
Not a friend, not a friend greet;
My poor corps, where my bones shall be thrown,
A thousand thousand sighs to save.
Lay me O where
True Lover never find my Grave
To weep there.

div.head: A BRIDALL SONG.
div.l: COme away, bring on the Bride,
And place her by her Lovers side;
You fair troop of Maids attend her,
Pure and holy thoughts attend her.
Blush, and wish you Virgins all
Many such fair nights may fall.
Hymen fill the house with joy,
All thy sacred fires imploy.
Blesse the Bed with holy Love,
Let nought but joy betwixt them move.

lg.l: A Way delights, go seek some other dwelling.
For I must die,
Farewell false Love, thy tongue is ever telling
Ly after lie.
For ever let me rest now from thy smarts,
Alas for pitty goe
And fire their hearts
That have been hard to thee, mine was not so.
Never again deluding Love shall know me,
For I will dye:
And all those griefs that think to over-grow me,
Shall be as I.
For ever will I sleep, while poor Maids cry
Alas for pitty stay
And let us dy.
With thee; Men cannot mock us in the day.

div.head: A SONG.
div.l: LOok out bright eyes and blesse the ayre,
Even in shadows you are fair:
Shut up beauty is like Fire,
That breaks out cleerer still and higher.
Though your body be confin'd,
And soft loft Love a Prisoner bound,
Yet the beauty of your mind
Neither check nor chain hath found.

div.head: A SONG.
div.l: VVHat I fancy, I approve,
No dislike there is in Love.
Be my Mistresse short or tall,
And distorted therewithall:
Be she likewise one of those,
That an acre hath of Nose;
Bee her forehead and her eyes
Full of incongruities:
Bee her cheeks so shallow too
As to shew her tongue-way through:
Be her lips ill-hung or set,
And her grinders black as jet;
Has she thin hair, has she none,
Shee's to me a Paragon.

div.head: A SONNET.
div.l: HOw Love came in I do not know,
VVhether by th'eye, or ear, or no;
Or whether with the Soul it came
(At first infused with the same;
VVhether in part 'tis here or there,
Or like the Soul, whole every where:
This troubles me, but I as well
As any other this can tell;
That when from hence she does depart,
The outlet then is from the heart.

lg.l: LOve, like a Gypsy, lately came,
And did much importune,
To see my hand, that by the same
He might foretell my fortune.
He saw my palme; and then said he,
I tell thee by this score here;
That thou within few moneths shalt be,
The youthfull Prince D'Amour here.
I smild, and bad him once more prove,
And by some crosse-line show it;
For I could ne'r be Prince of Love,
Though here the Princely Poet.
THou art to all lost Love the best,
The onely true plant found,
Wherewith young men and maids distrest,
And left of Love, are Crown'd.
When once the Lovers Rose is dead,
Or laid aside forlorne;
Then Willow Garlands, 'bout the head
Bedew'd with Teares are worne.
When with neglect (the Lovers bane)
Poore hearts rewarded bee;
For their Love Lost, their only gaine,
Is but a Wreath from thee.
And under-neath thy cooling shade,
(When weary of the Light)
The Love-spent youth and Love-sick Maid
Come to weepe out the Night.

div.head: A SONG TO VENVS.
div.l: GOddess, I doe love a Girle
Ruby Lipt and tooth'd with pearle;
If so be, I may but prove
Lucky in this Maide I Love:
I will promise there shall bee
Mirtles offer'd up to thee.

lg.l: VVHat Conscience, say is it in thee
When I a heart had one,
To take away that heart from mee
And to retaine thy owne?
For shame or pitty now incline
To play a loving part;
Either to send me kindly thine,
Or give me back my heart.
Covet not both, but if thou dost
Resolve to part with neither;
Why, yet to shew that thou art just,
Take me and mine together.
IN a Dreame Love bad me go
To the Gallyes there to Row;
In the Vision I ask't, why?
Love as briefly did Reply,
Twas better there to Toyle then prove
The turmoyles they indure that Love.
I awoke and then I knew,
VVhat love said to me was true:
Henceforth therefore I will be
As from Love, from trouble free.
None pitties him that's in the snare,
And warn'd before, would not beware.
GOe happy Rose and interwove
VVith other flowers, bind my Love,
Tell her too she must not be
Longer flowing, longer free,
That so oft has fetter'd me.
Say (if shee's fretfull) I have bands
Of Pearl, and Gold to bind her hands:
Tell her, if she struggle still,
I have Mirtle rods (at will)
For to tame, though not to kill.
Take thou my blessing thus, and go,
And tell her this, yet do not so,
Lest a handsome anger fly,
Like a lightning from her eye,
And burn thee up as well as I.
I Doe Love I know not what,
Sometimes this, and sometimes that,
All conditions I aime at.
But as lucklesse, I have yet
Many shrewd disasters met
To gain her, whom I would get.
Therefore now I'le love no more,
As I have doted heretofore,
He that must be, shall be poor.
Now the lusty Spring is seen,
Golden yellow, gaudy blew,
Daintily invite the view
Every where on every green;
Roses blushing as they blow,
And inticing men to pull;
Lilies whiter then the Snow,
Wood-bines of sweet Honey full.
All Loves emblems, and all cry,
Ladies if not pluck'd we die.
Yet the lusty Spring hath staid
Blushing red, and purest white,
Daintily to love invite
Every woman, every maid.
Cherries kissing as they grow,
And inviting men to tast;
Apples even ripe below,
Winding gently to the wast.
All Loves emblems, and all cry,
Ladies, if not pluck'd we die.

div.head: A SONG.
div.l: HOw long shall I pine for Love?
How long shall I sue in vain?
How long like the Turtle Dove
Shall I heartily thus complain?
Shall the sayles of my Love stand still?
Shall the grists of my hopes be unground?
Oh fie, Oh fie, Oh fie, Oh fie,
Let the Mill, let the Mill go round.

lg.l: ON the Bed Ile throw thee, throw thee down,
Down being laid, shall we be affraid
To try the rights that belong to Love?
No, no, there Ile wooe thee with a Crown;
Crown our desires,
Kindle the fires,
When Love requires, we should wanton prove.
Wee'l kisse, wee'l sport, wee'l laugh, wee'l play,
If thou com'st short, for thee Ile stay,
If thou unskilfull art, the ground
Ile kindly teach, while the Mill goes round.

div.head: A SONG.
div.l: Hence all you vain delights,
As short as are the nights;
VVherein you spend your folly.
There's nought in this life sweet,
If man were wise to see't
But only Melancholly,
Sweetest Melancholly.
Welcome folded armes and fixed eyes,
A sight that piercing mortifies;
A look that's fastned to the ground,
A tongue chain'd up without a sound.
Fountain heads and pathlesse Groves,
Places which pale passion Loves:
Moonlight walks, when all the fouls
Are warmly hous'd save Batts and Owles,
A midnight-Bell a parting grone.
These are the sounds we feed upon;
Then stretch our bones in a still gloomy vally,
Nothing so dainty sweet, as lovely Melancholly.

div.head: A SONG.
div.l: FAin would I awake you, sweet, but fear
I should invite you to worse chear;
In your dreams you cannot fare
Meaner then Musick, no compare;
None of your slumbers are compil'd
Under the pleasures makes a child:
Your day delights so well compact,
That what you think turnes all to act:
I'de wish my selfe no better play,
Your dream by night, your thought by day.
Wake gently, wake,
Part softly from your dreams;
The morning flies
To your fair eyes,
To take her speciall beams.

lg.l: HEar ye Ladies that despise
VVhat the mighty Love hath done,
Fear examples and be wise.
Fair Calisto was a Nun.
Leda sailing on the stream,
To deceive the hopes of man,
Love accounting but a dream,
Doated on a silver Swan.
Diana in a Brazen Tower,
Where no Love was, Lov'd a flower.
Hear ye Ladies that are coy,
What the mighty Love can do;
Fear the fiercenesse of the Boy,
The chast Moon he makes to wooe.
Vesta kindled holy fires,
Circled round about with spires,
Never dreaming loose desires,
Doating on the Altar dies.
Ilion in a short Tower higher,
He can once more both build and fire.
FLattering hope, away and leave me,
Shee'l not come, thou dost deceive me.
Hark the Cock crowes, the envious light
Chides away the silent Night:
Yet she comes not, O how I tyre
Betwixt cold fear and hot desire.
Here alone enforc'd to tarry
While the tedious minuts marry,
And get howers, those daies and years,
Which I count with sighs and fears:
Yet she comes not, O how I tyre,
Betwixt cold fear, and hot desire.
Restlesse thoughts a while remove
Into the bosome of my Love;
Let her languish in my pain,
Fear, and hope, and fear again:
What torments like unto desire.
Endlesse wishing, tedious longing,
Hopes and fears together thronging,
Rich in Dreams, though poor in waking,
Let her be in such a taking.
Then let her tell me in Loves fire
What torments like unto desire.
Come then Love, present daies eyeing
My desire would fain be doing:
Smother me with breathlesse kisses,
Let me dream no more of blisses:
But tell me which is in Loves fire,
Best to enjoy, or to desire.
MAy I find a woman fair,
And her mind as clear as ayre:
If her beautie go alone,
'Tis to me as if 'twere none.
May I find a woman rich,
And not of too high a pitch:
If that pride should cause disdain,
Tell me lover where's thy gain?
May I find a woman wise,
And her falshood not disguise;
Hath she wit as she hath will,
Double arm'd she is to ill.
May I find a woman kind,
And not wavering like the wind;
How should I call that love mine,
When 'tis his, and his, and thine?
May I find a woman true,
There is beauties fairest hue;
There is beauty, love, and witt,
Happy he can compasse it.
NEver more will I protest.
To love a woman, but in jest:
For as they cannot be true,
So to give each man his due,
When this wooing fitt is past,
Their affection cannot last.
Therefore if I chance to meet
With a Mistresse fair and sweet,
Shee my service shall obtain,
Loving for her Love again:
Thus much liberty I crave,
Not to be a constant slave.
But when we have try'd each other,
If she better like another,
Let her quickly change for me,
Then to change am I as free.
Hee or shee that Loves too long,
Sell their freedome for a song.
VVHy should man be only ty'd
To a Foolish Female thing,
When all creatures else beside,
Birds and beasts change every Spring?
Who would then to one be bound,
When so many may be found?
Why should I my selfe confine
To the limits of one place,
When I have all Europe mine,
Where I list to runne my race?
VVho would then to one be bound,
When so many may be found?
Would you think him wise that now
Still one sort of meat doth eat,
When both sea and Land allow
Sundry sorts of other meat?
Who would then to one be bound,
VVhen so many may be found?
Ere old Saturn chang'd his Throne,
Freedome raign'd, and banisht strife;
VVhere was he that knew his owne?
Or who call'd a woman wife?
VVho would then to one be bound,
VVhen so many may be found?
Ten times happier are those men
That enjoy'd those golden daies:
Untill time redrest again
I will never Hymen praise.
VVho would then to one be bound
VVhen so many may be found?
LEt fooles great Cupid's yoak disdain
Loving their owne wild freedome better,
VVhilst proud of my triumphant Chain
I sit and court my beautious Fetter.
Her murdering glances, snaring hairs,
And her bewitching smiles so please me;
As he brings ruine that repaires
The sweet afflictions that displease me.
Hide not those panting balls of snow,
VVith envious vails from my beholding;
Unlock those lips, their pearled row
In a sweet smile of love unfolding.
And let those eyes, whose motion wheeles
The restlesse fate of every Lover;
Survey the pains my sick-heart feeles,
And wounds themselves have made discover.
A Thief of late was hang'd you know
Because he had his part
Of stollen goods, and shalt thou scape
VVho stollen hast my heart?
Thou hadst my heart when it was whole,
For so I'me sure thou foundst it;
And would you give it me again
Now you have all bewound it.
No, reason would that recompence
Were had in any wise;
Perhaps you would give me mine own,
But that will not suffice.
The old Law saith, give eye for eye,
And tooth for tooth restore,
Then give me heart for heart again,
And I will ask no more.
LEANDER on the Bay
Of Hellespont all naked stood,
Impatient of delay,
He springs into the fatall flood.
The wrathfull seas
Whom none can please,
Their angry malice show;
The heavens did lowre,
The rain down powre,
The winds aloud did blow.
The Lad for succour craves,
And to the Triton God complaines,
Ye ragged Rocks and waves,
Ye Heavens, ye Thunder, storm and rains,
VVhat tis to miss
A Lovers bliss,
Alack you do not know,
Make me your wrack,
As I come back,
Oh spare me as I go.
Behold in yonder Tower
My fair beloved Hero lies
This the appointed hower;
Hark how she on Leander cries.
The Gods were mute
Unto his suit,
The billowes answer no;
The surges rise
Up to the skies,
And bring him down below.
The Lass mean while above
'Twixt hope and fear expected him,
Blaming sometimes his Love,
That cowardlike he durst not swim,
So that her tears,
Mov'd by those fears,
To such a height did grow;
That for to him
VVas lesse to swim,
Then her t'have lov'd him so.
Anon the approaching Sun,
VVith doubtfull light reveal'd his state
How Hero was undone
Not by Leanders fault, but Fate;
She meant to shew
That they were two,
Yet that their Loves were one;
That neither he
Could dye, nor she
Could ever live alone.
Her showring eyes with tears
Brought in the tyde before its time,
Her cries unto the ears
Of Jove with sad laments did climb;
O heavens quoth she
Against poor me
Do you your forces bend?
Ile leap the wall,
And down will fall
To meet my dying friend.
So from the Tower she leapt
Into the angry seas to him,
Wooing each wave she met
To teach her weary armes to swim:
Vntill that she
Might come to be
But by Leanders side,
She ariv'd at last
And grip'd him fast,
Sigh, wept, kiss'd, sunk, and dy'd.
O Love whose power and might,
No mortall ere withstood;
Thou forcest me to write,
Come turne about Robinhood.
Sole Mistresse of my heart,
Let me thus far presume;
To make this bold request,
A black patch for the Rheum.
Grant pitty or I die,
Love so my heart bewitches;
VVith grief I howle and cry,
Oh how my Elbow itches.
Teares overflow mine eyes,
And with flouds of daily weeping;
That in the silent night;
I cannot rest for sleeping.
VVhat i'st I would not doe,
To purchase one sweet smile;
Bid me to China goe,
Faith I'le sit still the while.
O VVomen you will never,
But think men still do flatter;
I vow I'le Love you ever,
But yet it is no matter.
Cupid is blind they say,
But yet me thinks be seeth:
He struck my heart to day,
AT— in Cupids teeth.
Her tresses that are wrought
Much like the golden snare;
My loving heart have caught
As Moss did catch his Mare.
But since that all relief
And comfort doth forsake me,
Ile kill my selfe with grief,
And then the Devill take me.
And since her gracefull merits
My loving Book must lack,
Ile stop my vitall spirits
With Claret or with Sack.
Mark well my wofull hap,
Jove Rector of the Thunder:
Send down thy thunder-clap
And rend her smock asunder.
YOur Letter I receiv'd
Bedeckt with flourishing quarters;
Because you are deceiv'd
Go hang you in your Garters.
My beauty, which is none
Yet such as you protest
Doth make you sigh and groan,
Fy, fy, you do but jest,
I cannot chuse but pitty
Your restlesse mournfull tears,
Because your plaints are witty,
You may go shake your ears.
To purchase your delight,
No labour you shall leese,
Your pains I will requite.
Maids fetch him bread and cheese.
Tis you I fain would see,
Tis you I daily think on;
My looks as kind shall be
As the devills over Lincoln.
If ever I do tame,
Great Jove of lightning Bashes;
Ile send my fiery flame
And burn thee into ashes.
I can by no means miss thee,
But needs must have thee one day:
I prithee come and kiss me
Whereon I sat on Sunday.
MAids they are grown so coy of late
Forsooth they will not marry,
Though they be in their teenes and past,
They say they yet can tarry.
But if they knew how sweet a thing
It were in youth to marry,
They'd sell their petticoats, smocks and al
Ere they so long would tarry.
The wench that is most coy of all,
If she had time and leasure,
Would lay by all her severall thoughts,
And turn to love and pleasure.
For even the wisest heads sometimes
Put on the face of folly;
And Maids do never more repent
Then when they are too holy.
Winter nights are long you know,
And bitter cold the weather;
Then who's so fond to lie alone
When two may lie together.
And is't not brave when summer's robes
Have all the fields encowled;
To have a green gown on the grass,
And wear it uncontrouled.
A Restlesse Lover I espide,
That walk'd from place to place,
Taht sat and turn'd from side to side,
And sometimes on his face.
But when as medicine were applyed
In hope of intermission;
Like one that found no ease, he cry'd
Hath Cupid no Physician.
What do those Ladies with their looks,
Their kisses and their smiles?
Can no receipt in loves sweet books
Restore their former spoiles?
No, they complain as well as we,
Their hopes have no remission;
And when both sexes wounded be
Hath Cupid no Physician?
Into what Palsyes, and what pains,
What feavours and what fits?
No quintescentiall Chymick graines
Prescrib'd by learned writs,
Nor creature can beneath the Sun
Invade in opposition,
And when such wonders may be donne
Hath Cupid no Physician?
Into what poyson do they dip
Their Arrowes, or their dart,
That touching but a fingers tip
They wound us to the heart?
And when precisely they do get
Into their inquisition:
Death never found a Surgeon yet,
Nor Cupid a Physician.

div.head: A SONG. In praise of Tobacco.
div.l: MUch meat doth gluttony procure
To feed men fat like Swine;
But hee's a frugall man indeed
That with a leafe can dine.
He needs no Napkin for his hands,
His fingers ends to wipe;
That hath his Kitchin in a box.
His Roastmeat in a Pipe.

lg.l: VVHy should we so much despise
So good and holy an exercise,
As early and late
To meditate
When ere we drink Tobacco.
The earthen Pipe so Lilly white,
Doth shew thou art a mortall wight;
Yea, even such
Broke with a touch.
Thus think, then drink Tobacco.
And when the smoak ascends on high
Think on this earthly vanity
Of worldly stuffe
Gone with a puffe.
Thus think, then drink Tobacco.
Lastly the ashes left behind
Do daily serve to move the wind,
That t'ashes and dust
Return we must.
Thus think, then drink Tobacco.

div.head: A SONG.
div.l: IF thou canst not live chast, Tempus est.
Then take a wife in hast. Tempus est.
But for feare of strife, Bonum est.
Be advis'd of a wife. Bonum est.
For this is true and plaine, Cavendum est.
If thou match for lucre & gaine. Cavendum est.
That she will in the end, Suspectum est.
Prove but a fickle friend. Suspectum est.
And if thou once canst prove Signum est.
She doth another Love. Signum est.
She meaneth to adorne Certum est.
Thy forehead with a horne. Certum est.
And when a man doth grow Monstrum est.
Much like a Buck you know, Monstrum est.
Each boy will in disgrace, Rejectum est.
Deride him to his face, Rejectum est.
And when that he doth dy, Horrendum est
And on his biere doth ly, Horrendum est
Each boy will then in jest, Cornutus est.
There write upon his Crest, Cornutus est.
And he that alwaies will, Stultus est.
Be rul'd by his wife still, Stultus est.
For this he sure shall find, Confutus est.
If she alwaies have her mind, Confutus est.
He that will needs be wed, Insanus est.
And bring a shrew to bed, Insanus est.
Who leades a single life, Quietus est.
He liveth void of strife, Quietus est.

div.head: LOVE-LETTER.
div.p: I Beseech you excuse my boldnesse in undertaking to declare unto you the martyrdome I suffer; your excellency, which is so much the more ardent in that I keepe it close, and covert: yet cannot the Reverence I beare you have so great a sway, but that my affection will needs discover it selfe unto you; be pleased then, with patience to heare my most humble suit, and apply some Cordiall to my wounded Heart, which lies hopelesse of remedy unlesse your Mercy vouchsafe a cure to

closer.signed: Your most devoted servant E. C.

div.head: ANOTHER.
div.p: IT is in vain for me to strive any longer against the streame, and I finde my selfe so unable to resist those inevitable charmes of your beauty, that willingly I render up my selfe your Captive, since it is as impossible to see you and not Love you, as it is for me to live without your Love; If my boldnesse stand in need of pardon; the excesse of my affection must pleade in my excuse; and I must hope for that from your mercy, which in justice you cannot well deny to the affection of

closer.signed: Your faithfull, &c.

div.head: ANOTHER.
div.p: SInce to love you, is the effect of your beauty, and since it is my fortune to be one of the number of your adorers; if this be a crime, you must accuse your beauty, that makes you be beloved, and my fates, for creating such a passion in me, as nothing but your beauty, or my death can satisfie; since then my destiny is in your hands, know Lady, 'tis the glory of your sex to be mercifull, and it will be more honour for you to save then to kill.

closer.signed: Your beauties admirer, C. C.

div.head: ANSWER.
div.p: I Have more discretion then to be tempted to give credit to your words; and it is not my custome to believe the complaints of Lovers; their afflictions do passe with me for Fables, and their diseases seem very easie to cure; and since you will needs enter your selfe into the list of those that can talk of more then they suffer, and pretend themselves possest with such a passion, that I believe none susceptible of, I shall desire you to forbear troubling your selfe and me, who am, and will be,

closer.signed: My owne, A. D.

div.head: ANOTHER.
div.p: SInce we are not bound to credit all that men speak or write, I hope you will not think amiss of me, if I am not overforward to believe you; and since men are so apt to change, we may well exact a long tryall of their constancy: amongst these, my selfe must claim some priviledge, and expect that time, and your services may perswade me as well as your words, of the reality of your affection: In the mean time I shall endeavour to avoid all the deceit may be used towards

closer.signed: Yours, as you serve her, K. P.

div.head: ANOTHER.
div.p:
VVHat you writ, I read with much impatience, to know what it was you would insinuate by your passionate expressions, excuse me if I think no otherwise of them, then meer flatteries,
since you pretend so suddenly to be taken with my small portion of beauty, which can boast of nothing but that it is not deformed; however, if I may be perswaded of the entirenesse of your Love, by the continuance of your services, I will induce my thoughts to entertain as favourable an opinion both of your person and passions, as in reason you can well hope for, or expect from

closer.signed: Your humble servant.

div.head: REPLY.
div.p: I Am so far from flatery, that I hate it; & if I would yet it were impossible for me to flatter you, since your beauty is above it; and did I but know, or think my selfe guilty of that great crime of dissimulation, I would employ it upon more unworthy objects then your most divine selfe; for I should account it as great a fault to play the dissembler with you, as the hypocrite with the Gods, and should expect to be punished as deeply for abusing your goodnesse, as for contemning their powers. But Madam, since my words and thoughts are twins, and that my hand writes the reall passions of my heart, let me conjure you to believe me, and know, that I shall sooner dye, then cease to be what I professe, which is.

closer.signed: Your faithfull servant, C. D.

div.head: ANOTHER.
div.p:
DId I know what testimonies you desired of my affection, and what assurance you would ask for my constancy, I would give you them: but time and
my faithfull services, shall take away all occasion of any suspicion you may harbour of my fidelity; and if you have any advantages of me, be pleased to continue them, and be assured that you shall never have any cause to repent of any kindnesse you do or may use to

closer.signed: Yaur eternally devoted servant, F. M.

div.head: ANOTHER.
div.p: COuld you but look into my heart, you would there see your beautious selfe so deeply ingraven, that you need not doubt that either time or fortune could ever be able to raise your Idea out of my thoughts; it will be needlesse therefore for you to doubt my truth, since I shall sooner forget my selfe, then the resolution I have taken both to live and die,

closer.signed: Your most constant and faithfull servant, A. M.

div.p: IT was my purpose to have set forth this ensuing discourse in way of addition to the Select thoughts of this Author, as I have intimated in my following Epistle; but now unexpectedly meeting with a fitter match for it, I send it abroad, as a seasonable Messenger of Comfort to all Christian Mourners,

closer.signed: G.H.

div.head: In the meane time the errors of the Presse, thus correct in the pages following,
div.p: IN the 2. Epistle page 4. everliving for underliving. p. 5. l. 16. flow for love. p. 6. l. 3. in for omni. p. 14. l. 11. soule for sort. p. 15. l. 11. be attyned for attaine. p. 22. l. 14. reverent for reverend. p. 41. l. 5. gaole for goale.
